The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Milton Dick ) took the chair at 09:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Appropriations and Administration Committee
Report
The SPEAKER (09:01): On behalf of the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Administration, I present the committee's report No. 32, Budget estimates 2025-26.
Report made a parliamentary paper in accordance with standing order 39(e).
BILLS

QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
Member for Moreton

Mr BROADBENT (Monash) (09:02): I have noticed with interest this week that your grace has been upon the member for Moreton in that you haven't ejected him from the chamber. I'm just wondering whether your grace will extend through question time today.
The SPEAKER (09:03): I'm happy to report to the member for Monash that the grace will continue.
COMMITTEES
Public Works Joint Committee
Approval of Work
Dr LEIGH (Fenner—Assistant Minister for Competition, Charities and Treasury and Assistant Minister for Employment) (09:03): I move:

That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Australian Electoral Commission—Proposed fit-out of new leased premises at 26 Narellan Street, Canberra.

The Australian Electoral Commission is proposing works to fit out leased premises at 26 Narellan Street, Canberra, ACT. The new office will consolidate three existing commercial tenancies for which leases will expire across 2026 to 2027. The new tenancy will then allow the commission to consolidate its staff presence and improve operational efficiencies for enhanced collaboration, as well as provide for an uplift in security. The estimated project cost is $35.9 million, excluding GST. The proposed works were referred to the public works committee on 12 December 2024. Following its inquiry, the committee recommended that the House of Representatives resolve that it is expedient to carry out the proposed works. Subject to parliamentary approval, the works are expected to commence in June 2026 and be completed by August 2027.
On behalf of the government, I would like to thank the committee, ably chaired by the member for Moreton, for undertaking a timely inquiry. I commend the motion to the House.
Question agreed to.
Approval of Work
Dr LEIGH (Fenner—Assistant Minister for Competition, Charities and Treasury and Assistant Minister for Employment) (09:05): I move:

That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Australian Institute of Sport revitalisation project, Canberra.

The Australian Sports Commission is proposing works to revitalise the Australian Institute of Sport campus in Bruce, Australian Capital Territory, and not before time. The proposed works will provide three new facilities: a new athletes village, a multisports dome and a high-performance training and testing centre incorporating sports science and sports medicine. The estimated cost of the project is $249.7 million, excluding GST. The proposed works were referred to the public works committee on 20 November 2024. Following its inquiry, the committee recommended the House of Representatives resolve that it is expedient to carry out the proposed works. Subject to parliamentary approval, construction is expected to commence from October 2025 and be completed by March 2027.

On behalf of the government, I would like to thank the committee for undertaking a timely inquiry. As a member for the ACT, I would like to thank those involved in this exciting project. As a sports nut, I am extraordinarily excited by what the new AIS will become. I commend the motion to the House.
Question agreed to.
Approval of Work
Dr LEIGH (Fenner—Assistant Minister for Competition, Charities and Treasury and Assistant Minister for Employment) (09:07): I move:

That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Department of Climate Change, Energy, the Environment and Water—Davis Station critical infrastructure works.

The Department of Climate Change, Energy, the Environment and Water is proposing to undertake a program of works to sustain and renew infrastructure at Davis research station in Antarctica. The scope of works will include a new water production and main power facility, new vehicle workshop, refurbishment of trade workshops, and the decommissioning and demolition of redundant structure. The estimated cost of the works is $251.7 million, excluding GST. The proposed works were referred to the public works committee on 6 November 2024. Following its inquiry, the committee recommended that the House of Representatives resolve that it is expedient to carry out the proposed works. Subject to parliamentary approval, construction is expected to commence in mid-2025 and be completed in mid-2030.
On behalf of the government, I would like to thank the committee for undertaking a timely inquiry. I commend the motion to the House.
Question agreed to.
Approval of Work
Dr LEIGH (Fenner—Assistant Minister for Competition, Charities and Treasury and Assistant Minister for Employment) (09:08): I move:

That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Department of Climate Change, Energy, the Environment and Water—Southern Ocean research aquarium.

The Department of Climate Change, Energy, the Environment and Water is proposing to develop a replacement cold-water marine research aquarium to be co-located at the University of Tasmania's Taroona site. The proposed works include the production of research areas, a deep tank, a sea-ice research freezer, feed and culture rooms for phytoplankton and other species, a marine laboratory and cold room, and supporting infrastructure and services.
Ms Collins: Saving the skate.

Dr LEIGH: Saving the skate, I am informed by the member for Franklin. The estimated total capital cost for the construction project is $36.7 million, excluding GST. The proposed works were referred to the public works committee on 20 November 2024. Following its inquiry, the committee has recommended that the House of Representatives resolve that it is expedient to carry out proposed works. Subject to parliamentary approval, the works are expected to commence in March 2026 for completion by September 2027.
On behalf of the government, I would like to thank the committee, ably chaired by the member for Moreton, for undertaking a timely inquiry. I commend the motion to the House.
Question agreed to.
Approval of Work
Dr LEIGH (Fenner—Assistant Minister for Competition, Charities and Treasury and Assistant Minister for Employment) (09:10): I move:

That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Department of Defence—Facilities to support LAND 8113 Phase 1 Long Range Fires.

Defence is proposing works to provide new facilities and infrastructure at the Edinburgh Defence Precinct, South Australia, to support a regiment to operate and maintain a new long-range fires capability. At this point, those listening carefully to parliament might have wondered, 'Why did he say "fires" rather than "firing"?' For those unfamiliar with the term, 'fires' is a doctrinal term used in military strategy which encompasses all forms of long-range offensive action—not just traditional artillery but also missiles, rockets, drone, air strikes and electronic attacks. It is plural and abstract, like 'forces' or 'operations'.

Defence is also proposing works to upgrade and reuse existing training sustainment and storage facilities at the School of Artillery at the Puckapunyal Military Area, Victoria, to also support the new capability. The total estimated cost of the works is $376.7 million, excluding GST.

The proposed works were referred to the public works committee on 6 November 2024. Following its inquiry, the committee recommended that the House of Representatives resolve that it is expedient to carry out the proposed works. Subject to parliamentary approval, the works at Edinburgh are scheduled to commence in late 2025 and be completed by late 2028. The works at Puckapunyal are scheduled to commence in mid-2026 and be completed by late 2026.
On behalf of the government, I would like to thank the committee for undertaking a timely inquiry. I commend the motion to the House.
Question agreed to.
Approval of Work
Dr LEIGH (Fenner—Assistant Minister for Competition, Charities and Treasury and Assistant Minister for Employment) (09:12): I move:

That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Services Australia—Proposed fit-out of existing leased premises at Caroline Chisholm Centre, 57 Athllon Drive, Greenway, Australian Capital Territory.

Services Australia is proposing works to fit out its existing premises at the Caroline Chisholm Centre, 57 Athllon Drive, Greenway, ACT. The works form part of a project that will consolidate three of Services Australia's Tuggeranong sites into one by 2027 and deliver operational and financial efficiencies. The estimated cost of the works is $144.49 million, excluding GST. The proposed works were referred to the public works committee on 6 November 2024. Following its inquiry, the committee recommended that the House of Representatives resolve that it is expedient to carry out the proposed works. Subject to parliamentary approval, construction is expected to commence in August 2025 and be completed in August 2027.
On behalf of the government, I would like to thank the committee, ably chaired by the member for Moreton, for undertaking a timely inquiry. I commend the motion to the House.
Question agreed to.
Approval of Work
Dr LEIGH (Fenner—Assistant Minister for Competition, Charities and Treasury and Assistant Minister for Employment) (09:14): I move:

That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Services Australia—Proposed fit-out of new leased premises at 158-186 Walker Street, Townsville, Queensland.

Services Australia is proposing works to fit out new leased premises at 158-186 Walker Street, Townsville, Queensland. The fit-out is part of a project to consolidate Services Australia's two Townsville corporate office sites, located in Aitkenvale and at 235-259 Stanley Street, into a single building. The estimated cost of the works is $29.16 million, excluding GST. The proposed works were referred to the public works committee on 6 November 2024. Following its inquiry, the committee recommended that the House of Representatives resolve that it is expedient to carry out the proposed works. Subject to parliamentary approval, construction is expected to commence in early 2025 for completion in late 2027.
On behalf of the government, I would like to thank the committee, ably chaired by that great Queenslander the member for Moreton, for undertaking a timely inquiry. I commend the motion to the House.
Question agreed to.
Privileges and Members' Interests Committee
Report

Mr ROB MITCHELL (McEwen) (09:16): In accordance with standing order 216, on behalf of the Standing Committee of Privileges and Members' Interests, I present a report concerning the registration and declaration of members' interests during 2024. I would also like to thank the committee members for their collegiality in the 47th Parliament and the committee staff for their hard work and diligence.
Report made a parliamentary paper in accordance with standing order 39(e).

span.span: Ms Susan Templeman MP Chair—Petitions Committee

p.span: PETITIONS
Presentation
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (09:16): by leave—I present 112 petitions:
Bitcoin
El Salvador adopted Bitcoin as legal tender and began buying in September 2021. Coinciding with social reform, El Salvador has begun a new economic growth phase, reflected in their GDP.
US companies are now following El Salvador's lead, buying Bitcoin to be used as collateral for future growth opportunities.

The US president-elect has recently promised to institute a US Bitcoin Strategic Reserve. This will act similarly to the Gold Reserves held by central banks around the world, but will be fully auditable simply by sharing the US government's public wallet address. This transparency and accountability helps foster trust in their financial system.
The US Bitcoin Reserve is already in motion in states like Wyoming, and has already found support from massive companies such as Blackrock.

By having the Australian Treasury adopt a similar strategy, the Australian economy can be insulated from the devaluing influence of its geopolitical contemporaries. The sovereign fund can help foster trust in both the national economy and monetary system, by boosting collateral (for borrowing) and transparency (by proving our sovereign assets on- chain).
If Australia moves expeditiously, we could capture a huge portion of the capital growth surge that will coincide with the US adoption, netting huge capital growth similar to El Salvador.
The faster Australia moves with this wave, the better.

We therefore ask the House to legislate the creation of a Sovereign Bitcoin Fund and begin purchasing Bitcoin to quickly build a national holding, then dedicate a percentage of annual Budget surplus to continued monthly Bitcoin purchases.
from eight citizens (Petition No. EN6893)
Cybersafety
The social media ban is very rushed and broad. The major stakeholders (teens) haven't been properly consulted or given a chance to comment.

We therefore ask the House to delay legislation until we have had a chance to have a national discussion to come up with a solution to the challenges social media presents. We request for teens to be included and their input to be considered in the social media ban.
from 26 citizens (Petition No. EN6896)

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Embassy: United States of America

p.span: Australian Embassy: United States of America

The relationship between Australia and the United States of America, while significant, must be rooted in honesty, accountability, and mutual respect. The role of the ambassador is not to appease political figures but to represent Australian values and interests. Having an ambassador like Kevin Rudd, who has demonstrated a willingness to speak out on important global issues, reflects Australia's commitment to principled diplomacy.

We therefore ask the House to uphold Kevin Rudd's appointment as the Ambassador to the United States. His presence in this post, even as President Trump takes office, is a testament to Australia's independence and ability to stand firm on its principles. Removing him would send a message of weakness, undermining the integrity of the relationship we have carefully cultivated over the past century.
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN6902)
School Student Broadband Initiative

Currently, eligible students of low-income families receive free broadband internet through the School Student Broadband Initiative, something undeniably essential to success at school in today's digital world. This initiative is set to run until December 2025, with students who receive internet (who likely cannot afford the facility) then either having their service cancelled, or made to switch to a paid plan after the month.

We therefore ask the House to ensure that this program is extended into the future, and ensure students who face financial disadvantage are not further left behind without adequate access to digital services.
from 71 citizens (Petition No. EN6903)

subdebateinfo.title: Litchfield National Park: Invasive Species Management

p.span: Litchfield National Park: Invasive Species Management

Scientists say that Litchfield National Park is heading towards "ecosystem" collapse and potential risk to visitor safety, due to the spread of invasive gamba grass and the very hot wildfires it brings (Rossiter-Rachor et al, 2023 "The cost of not acting: Delaying invasive grass management increases costs and threatens assets in a national park, northern Australia"). They say that every year action is delayed makes it more and more costly and difficult to address this problem.

These scientists propose a gamba management option for the Park which they say would protect it's most precious biodiversity and tourism areas from this threat. This would involve a five-year eradication strategy within a prescribed area, which they cost at $7m (which scientists note may be reduced if aerial herbicide spraying is used). However after this five-year eradication program, annual gamba control costs within the Park would drop significantly to $111, 000 (close to the amount the NT Government has been allocating for this purpose in recent years .

The previous NT Government never responded to the scientists' report, and we are concerned that the new NT Government (elected in August) will not invest sufficiently to protect the future of Litchfield. That would mean the impending loss of a key northern Australian biodiversity and tourism asset, also important for local Indigenous people.

We therefore ask the House to urge the Australian Government to urgently seek negotiations with the NT Government to support funding of the five-year gamba grass eradication program proposed by scientists.
from 186 citizens (Petition No. EN6909)
Cost of Living

I want to know how many people in Australia (who lodge an annual tax return) have earned less than the $18,200 tax free part? Can the govt officially publish these figures for the tax years ending 2021, 2022, 2023 & 2024 to see the extent of the problem.
What use is the govt's cost of living relief like tax cuts, Medicare levy relief & low income Offset relief etc, if a person earning less than $18,200 cannot benefit from it?
These people earning less than $18,200 cannot survive in these circumstances.
We therefore ask the House to pass legislation to publish the figures requested above & increase the Family Assistance & Carer payments Allowances dramatically, so families can survive.
from 45 citizens (Petition No. EN6912)
Telecommunications
Background:

Coomera Waters is a tranquil and picturesque community, home to approximately 5,000 residents. Despite its status, our connectivity infrastructure falls significantly below acceptable standards, leaving residents frustrated, isolated, and at risk.
Key Issues:
Unreliable Internet Services:
The estate relies on Opticomm, a private fibre network, which frequently experiences outages lasting hours.
There is no NBN available, and while costly upgrades are possible, they fail to resolve the core reliability issues.
Alternative solutions, such as Starlink, are unavailable in South East Queensland due to capacity constraints.
Limited Mobile Reception:
Telstra is the sole mobile service provider, but its signal strength is weak, often leaving residents with one bar or requiring them to stand in driveways to make or receive calls.
With Telstra undergoing maintenance, many residents risk losing mobile coverage entirely.
Community Impact:
Residents are unable to make critical calls during emergencies due to poor mobile reception.
Families face significant challenges with remote work and online education due to constant internet disruptions.
These issues undermine the livability and safety of a community that prides itself on being a premium suburb.
We therefore ask the House to respectfully request that the Federal Government and relevant authorities take immediate action to:
1. Advocate for urgent upgrades to internet and mobile infrastructure in Coomera Waters.
2. Work with service providers like Opticomm to explore sustainable solutions or facilitate the transition to the NBN network.
3. Ensure reliable mobile coverage by engaging with Telstra and other providers to improve signal strength and capacity.
from 133 citizens (Petition No. EN6913)
Early Childhood Education
Children under five with disabilities in the Australia are being failed by the early education system.

Discrimination is widespread as centre's lack the funding, training, and resources needed to support these children. Families are turned away or forced to settle for inadequate care because many educators are unprepared to meet the needs of diverse learners. This exclusion violates fundamental principles of equality and denies children with disabilities their right to early education, a critical foundation for lifelong learning.

Current funding does not address the additional requirements of children with disabilities, leaving centre's unable to provide specialized staff, adaptive tools, or integrated therapy. Without urgent action, this inequity will persist, depriving countless children of the chance to reach their full potential.

We therefore ask the House to eliminate discrimination in early education by addressing funding and resource gaps in Australia. Increase funding for early learning centre's to hire specialized staff, provide adaptive resources, and integrate therapy services for children with disabilities. Mandate and fund comprehensive training programs for early educators to ensure they can effectively support diverse learners. Strengthen accountability measures to enforce anti-discrimination laws and ensure equitable access for all children.

Introduce a targeted support package for families, including financial assistance and access to early intervention services. These actions are essential to creating an inclusive education system that upholds the rights of all children and reflects Australia's values of equality and opportunity. Every child deserves the chance to thrive—this begins with equitable early education.
from 185 citizens (Petition No. EN6914)
Mental Health

Mental health medication has seen a dramatic increase of price under the Labor Government. Since Labor has been in power the Health Minister has been praising about how Labor is making medication more affordable. This has been the complete opposite for medications to treat mental health conditions such as venlafaxine a common antidepressants have seen a rise of up to $10 a month. Antidepressants and other medications for mental health aren't included on the 60 day prescription plan. With the rising number of people who have been diagnosed with mental health conditions over the past few years, more people need to rely on medication, yet it is unaffordable for some.

We therefore ask the House to have an immediate investigation into the supply and price of mental health medication. We call the health minister look into more funding to lower the price of medication to treat mental health conditions as this problem has been ongoing for nearly 3 years now.
from 53 citizens (Petition No. EN6918)
Taxation: Tobacco

Australian government has risen the tobacco tax to be the most expensive in the world pushing its people to buy illegal cigarettes that we do not know how it's made and we're its made and other products like vape products and weed is actually cheaper today than tobacco most of stealing happening and other crimes including drug selling and drug taking are always linked to spike in cigarette price the government should end this by halfing its taxes this should be done

We therefore ask the House to actually do this most kids today are using vapes and others mixing tobacco with herbs just to smoke and 70% of the market tobacco is illegal tobacco were its not from a real manufacturer and no government inspection ever went thru today Street drugs are cheaper than Australian cigarettes this has a end 2025 were government has to half its tax's to stop criminal activity either from overseas to Australia and many other will have a change we see staff that you cannot see while sitting in the chair we hear what you cannot hear in the parliament house your windows are closed after this all vaping products should be banned not taxed! We can wait for other countries to see the long run affect we know the affect of tobacco but we don't know the affect of vape and cheap made cigarettes and chop chop ingredients.
from 56 citizens (Petition No. EN6919)
National Disability Insurance Scheme

Allow Neurodivergent Individuals With Multiple Disabilities and Complex Needs To Choose How They Spend Their NDIS Social and Community Support Funds Without Blocking Essential Activities Needed For Their Physical and Mental Wellbeing Demonstrated By Their Medical Professionals.
We therefore ask the House to Restore The Previously Awarded Rights To Neurodivergent Individuals Regardless of New Legislation Bill
from 51 citizens (Petition No. EN6920)
Electoral Reform

This significant electoral reform bill demands thorough examination due to its potential far-reaching impacts on our democratic processes. Rushing such complex legislation without proper scrutiny could undermine public trust and confidence in our electoral system.

While we acknowledge the urgent need to address the influence of substantial financial contributions on our democracy, we believe that a bill of this magnitude requires rigorous analysis and expert input. The current form of the bill may not effectively achieve its intended goal of curbing the impact of large donations in politics, as it contains potential loopholes allowing substantial contributions to political parties above the proposed annual donation cap.

Furthermore, the bill in its present state could inadvertently strengthen the advantage of major parties and incumbents while having disadvantages for independent and challenger candidates. This outcome could potentially erode, rather than enhance, the fairness of our democratic system.

We therefore ask the House to initiate a parliamentary inquiry to ensure that any changes to our electoral system are carefully considered, thoroughly vetted, and ultimately serve to strengthen the integrity and fairness of our democracy.
from 82 citizens (Petition No. EN6924)

subdebateinfo.title: National Disability Insurance Scheme: Music Therapy

p.span: National Disability Insurance Scheme: Music Therapy

Music therapy provides essential, evidence-based support to NDIS participants, assisting with communication, emotional regulation, and social connection—unique benefits that often cannot be fully met by other therapies. Removing NDIS funding for music therapy would deprive many individuals with disabilities of a therapeutic service that significantly enhances their quality of life. This decision will prevent participants from accessing a service that helps them achieve meaningful milestones, build confidence, and thrive in ways that promote long-term well-being and growth. Beyond the impact on participants, this change will result in the loss of countless jobs for Registered Music Therapists across Australia, eliminating a whole sector of allied health. As a result, access to music therapy will be severely restricted, limiting this critical resource for both current and future NDIS participants.

We therefore ask the House to recognise the invaluable role of music therapy within the NDIS framework and to not remove Music Therapy as an NDIS funded support which is to occur on 2nd December 2024. We ask you to consult with The Australian Music Therapy Association (AMTA), to consult with those with disabilities who have benefited from music therapy and understand the therapeutic benefits of music therapy.
from 16 citizens (Petition No. EN6926)
Domestic and Family Violence

Every day, domestic violence devastates families, leaving lasting scars on individuals and communities. It's time to take action. Clare's Law (also known at the Domestic Violence Disclosure Scheme—DVDS) is named after Clare Wood, who tragically lost her life to domestic violence. The law provides individuals with the right to access vital police information about a partner's history of abuse.

Proven effective in countries like the UK, New Zealand, and Canada, Clare's Law empowers individuals with knowledge to make informed decisions and seek safety. Despite its success abroad, this life-saving measure is yet to be adopted nationwide in Australia.
We therefore ask the House to
Work with the Council of Australian Governments (COAG) or its replacement, the National Cabinet, to develop a national framework for Clare's Law.
Provide funding or resources to support states and territories in implementing Clare's Law (DVDS).
Advocate for uniform adoption of Clare's Law (DVDS) across Australia.
from 913 citizens (Petition No. EN6927)
Medicare: Allied Health

The aim of this petition is to gather support for people who have undergone breast reconstruction after mastectomy and who would like to have intradermal colouration of nipple or areola or both (medical tattooing) performed by a qualified, registered Paramedical Tattooist with a higher Medicare rebate.

We therefore ask the House to consider allowing the integration of qualified and regulated Paramedical Tattooists into the Australian Medicare system and raising the rebate from the current $191. By including these highly trained professionals, we can ensure that high standards of aesthetically pleasing and artistically rendered medical tattoos, such as 3D nipples, are achieved. This can significantly enhance the quality of life and mental health outcomes for patients compared to the results often seen with hospital-performed tattoos where most haven't been given adequate training to perform to an acceptable standard and comfortably execute such an important closure of someone's breast cancer experience, leading to negative psychological and emotional outcomes.
from 914 citizens (Petition No. EN6928)
Domestic and Family Violence

Many victims of domestic violence are wrongly identified as perpetrators due to inadequate investigative practices and manipulation of the system by true aggressors. This misidentification causes severe trauma, criminalization, and legal repercussions for victims, while the real perpetrators evade accountability.

This failure undermines the goals of the National Plan to End Violence against Women and Children 2022-2032, which emphasizes victim-centered justice, holding perpetrators accountable, and protecting children. Misidentification perpetuates cycles of abuse, damages public trust in the justice system, and leaves children vulnerable to ongoing harm by remaining in the care of the true perpetrators.
Addressing this issue is critical to ensuring justice for victims, deterring the misuse of domestic violence protections, and upholding the integrity of Australia's response to family violence.
We therefore ask the House to
Develop a national database to track and address victim misidentification in domestic violence cases.
Introduce legislative reforms mandating thorough investigative protocols to prevent misidentification and ensure victim-centered justice.
Implement criminal penalties for true perpetrators, including those who manipulate the system through false accusations.
Provide training for law enforcement and judiciary on identifying primary aggressors and understanding domestic violence dynamics.
Establish mechanisms to clear records of misidentified victims and provide restitution and support, ensuring alignment with the National Plan to End Violence against Women and Children 2022-2032.
These actions will protect victims, hold true perpetrators accountable, and restore public confidence in the justice system.
from 20 citizens (Petition No. EN6935)
Australian Broadcasting Corporation
Legacy media is dead, and tax payers should not be funding the ABC.
We therefore ask the House to defund the ABC
from 25 citizens (Petition No. EN6937)

subdebateinfo.title: National Disability Insurance Scheme: Music Therapy

p.span: National Disability Insurance Scheme: Music Therapy

The Minister for NDIS has allowed the Australian Music Therapy Association to block holders of the Bachelor of Music Education degree from using what they are trained for, to teach ADD, ADHD and all Special Learners' needs.
As such, the NDIS Minister through provisioning the AMTA to exclude Ba Mus Ed is effectively dismissing a university qualification specifically for this field.
A qualification that also requires thousands of dollars in HECS.
Even though until recent changes, NDIS recipients under teachers of Ba Mus Ed in Music Therapy achieved effective service and outcomes.
We therefore ask the House to
Acknowledge that the Ba Mus Ed degree encompasses ADHD and Special Learning methods.
Allow Bachelor of Music Education holders to be recognised by the NDIS for Music in Therapy.
To join the Australian Music Therapist Association
from 171 citizens (Petition No. EN6939)
Bill of Rights
This petition of concerned citizens of Australia highlights the urgent need for a Bill of Rights. We believe this is crucial for several reasons:
Protection of Freedoms: Enshrining civil liberties ensures legal protection for all Australians, including freedoms of speech, assembly, and religion.
Equality and Justice: It provides a framework to combat discrimination, ensuring dignity and respect for everyone.

Democratic Strength: Recognizing rights empowers citizens and fosters active participation in society. Legal Clarity: It offers clear guidelines for courts and lawmakers, enhancing trust in our legal system.
Global Leadership: Demonstrates Australia's commitment to human rights and sets an international standard.
We request immediate action to draft and implement a comprehensive Bill of Rights, reflecting our shared values for a fairer Australia.

We therefore ask the House to act decisively in enacting a Bill of Rights. The absence of such a document leaves Australians vulnerable to inconsistencies and injustices that undermine our democratic values. This is an opportunity to affirm our commitment to equality, justice, and freedom for all.

Let us lead by example, demonstrating our dedication to human rights and setting a global standard. This is not just a legislative necessity; it is a moral imperative. Together, let us ensure every Australian can live with dignity and security, making Australia a beacon of hope and fairness in the world.
from 51 citizens (Petition No. EN6943)
Illicit Drugs: Cannabis

Cannabis in brownies doesn't cause cancer and it doesn't ruin the environment. Smoking is legal and it causes a lot of cancer, has killed more people than war, and illicit drugs and has worse effects than overdosing on cannabis. If taken correctly and responsibly cannabis is not as dangerous as alcohol or over the counter medicines and less dangerous than food. Those who do blame cannabis for mental illness are already predisposed to getting mentally sick and are gullible into thinking their unique brain chemistry is the result of illicit drugs. Lots of those who do have mental illness have never done drugs therefore it's safe and those who are weak should just stay away from drugs and junk food. It would bring in a lot of money and make Melbourne a more fun place to be. If there were cafes like they have in Amsterdam and only sold to eighteen year olds then Melbourne could greatly benefit just as Amsterdam has. They could look forward to an increase in hundreds of millions of dollars of profit and would boost the economy .
We therefore ask the House to legalise cannabis cafes
from 49 citizens (Petition No. EN6950)
Defence Personnel

They are risking their lives and getting rid of threats to our country and they should be paid more for doing that. Their life is worth just as much as anyone else's. We need to appreciate the sacrifice they make for others. Tax payers wouldn't have a job or a life without them and they deserve to thank them for their duty, service and sacrifice or else none us of would be alive.
We therefore ask the House to get tax payers to pay more taxes for soldiers
from six citizens (Petition No. EN6951)
Political Advertising

With the ban of children under 16 from Social Media, your petitioners wish to make it unlawful for any politician to use or post any images of children, including their own, on any form of social media. Posting images of children with politicians would prompt children to use social media to view or download these images and would constitute a breach of the The Online Safety Amendment (Social Media Minimum Age) Bill 2024. A Politician posting images that include children could be in breach of 63C (1) Where the platform is the page run or managed by that politician for the purposes of advertising a political message. In the Voller decision, the High Court confirmed that administrators of Facebook pages may be considered the 'publishers' of posts made by its members and therefore may be held personally liable.

We therefore ask the House to place a blanket ban on all politicians from using children under 16 for the promotion of policies and of self-promotion of themselves using children as a port for their self- promotion.
from 12 citizens (Petition No. EN6953)

subdebateinfo.title: National Disability Insurance Scheme: Art Therapy

p.span: National Disability Insurance Scheme: Art Therapy

It took me 5 years to find an Art Therapist who would travel to my rural area. I have just found an opening in her long local list. I am isolated because of my rural location and cannot get to the city to access this service. Art Therapy gives me practical expression of my mental health issues and I find I remember more of the mental health solutions by expressing them through art during the therapy sessions. Losing Art Therapy would be a huge disadvantage to me and many other disabled people with mental and physical therapy needs.
We therefore ask the House to ensure Art and Music Therapy remain on the NDIS list of approved therapies.
from 163 citizens (Petition No. EN6958)
Glyphosate

Glyphosate has been linked to numerous health issues, including cancer and liver disease. In fact, the International Agency for Research on Cancer has classified glyphosate as "probably carcinogenic to humans". Despite this, its use remains largely unregulated in Australia.

We call on the Australian government to immediately ban the use of glyphosate in all farming and agricultural practices. We cannot sit idly by and watch our health deteriorate simply because of a lack of adequate regulation. Please sign this petition to protect our health and our home.
We therefore ask the House to immediately ban the use of glyphosate in all farming and agricultural practices.
from 43 citizens (Petition No. EN6962)
Drug Abuse and Addiction

Australia faces a critical challenge with substance abuse, impacting individuals, families, and communities nationwide. Despite the availability of evidence-based harm reduction and treatment programs, many Australians are unable to access these services due to underfunding and limited resources. This has resulted in preventable health crises, including overdose deaths, the spread of diseases like hepatitis C and HIV, and long-term social and economic consequences.

Comprehensive harm reduction services, such as needle exchange programs, opioid substitution therapy, and safe consumption spaces, have proven to significantly reduce health risks. Similarly, expanding access to residential rehabilitation centers and community-based treatment programs offers people struggling with substance abuse a genuine pathway to recovery. Addressing this issue is not only a moral imperative but also a cost-effective strategy to improve public health and strengthen communities.

We therefore ask the House to allocate increased federal funding to evidence-based harm reduction programs, including needle and syringe exchange, opioid substitution therapy, and safe consumption facilities. We further request expanded investment in residential rehabilitation centers and community treatment programs to ensure accessibility across all regions, particularly underserved and remote areas.

Additionally, we urge the government to launch a nationwide education and prevention campaign to inform Australians about the risks of substance misuse and available support services. By taking these steps, the federal government can save lives, reduce harm, and empower communities to combat substance abuse effectively.
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN6964)
Telecommunications
This petition opposes the construction of an NBN telecommunications tower that will overshadow and encroach upon the Old School community site, negatively impacting its landscape and character.

The Scenic Rim Regional Council (SRRC) is breaching its own telecommunications code, which requires protection of important views and ridgelines, prohibits obstructing views from roads or public spaces, and mandates a 200-metre buffer from childcare centres, community hubs, schools, or parks.

The community site, gifted by the SRRC, hosts vital activities such as a café, markets, craft and art groups, fitness classes, children's educational events, and a community garden. It is also a designated night landing site for emergency helicopters.
For over 50 years, hang gliders and paragliders pilots from around the world have soared our skies and this tower poses a significant safety risk, as their launch and landing area is within 1km.
Additionally, this area is home to endangered species like Red-tailed black cockatoos, Glossy black cockatoo and Richmond Birdwing butterflies, which would be adversely affected.

The World Health Organisation recognise potential long-term health effects, such as DNA disruption hence this underscores the need to reject this proposal. The tower will diminish property values with its visual pollution and environmental and health impact. Our residents have invested their life savings and years of hard work into their homes and land such as organic farming.
We urge the SRRC to honour its commitments to community and environmental protection.
We therefore ask the House to cease this development on this community site.
from 85 citizens (Petition No. EN6973)
Property Valuation

Common sense is not being used by valuers when completing a valuation for a client or bank. Over the many years I have been in finance, I have sat on meetings where valuers have been guest speakers advising finance brokers to supply photos and sales evidence (which is their job) when requesting a valuation (so what do they do for their fee?).
Generally some banks asborb the cost however some banks charge this on to the client with some valuers also charging a further $110 to sometimes $1500 above standard fee which is a money grab.

Furthermore, the valuation comes back with irrelevant or outdated sales evidence and amounts varying from $25k to $1M and when you go to challenge this with the valuer, they generally say "we are not changing this".

How can we have such a huge variance when they should all be qualified. If the valuation is not aligned to estimate or they cannot substantiate the cost or variance, a refund in fee to the bank or client should be considered as brokers can only challenge this with supporting sales evidence.

We therefore ask the House to have some regulation around valuers so they are accountable for their actions rather than not care about the clients and banks they are working for, and also be charged for fee to be refunded if inadequate value or supplied outdated information to support their values.
from 31 citizens (Petition No. EN6974)
Banking and Financial Services
Banks ripping everyone
We therefore ask the House to establish a community bank. Run by the government . The bank system is rip off everyone a community bank with no unessesery fees should be established
from 20 citizens (Petition No. EN6975)
Banking and Financial Services

You should not be able to charge people to withdraw their own money from their own bank. Most people in this country pay interest or fees to banks for their credit cards or loans, why should they be charged a fee to access their own money?
We therefore ask the House to ban banks from charging customers to withdraw their own money from bank branch ATMs
from 80 citizens (Petition No. EN6976)
Mental Health
Mental health is an enduring problem in Australia and one that requires our attention.
Last year, over 3,000 Australians or 9 Australians each day died by suicide.
This is not okay. We need to change this statistic.
Behind every statistic there is a grieving father, a grieving mother, a grieving son, a grieving daughter and grieving friends. Every life matters.

Despite a growing wealth of emerging evidence about the harms social media has on particularly young adolescent, teenage minds, these companies have not contributed and paid their fair share to mental health support services and suicide prevention workshops.
We therefore ask the House to levy the net profits of social companies operating and earning an income by doing business in Australia.
Please call Life Line on 13 11 14 or Suicide Call Back Service on 1300 659 467 if this petition has raised any emotions or concerns with your own mental health.
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN6977)
Animal Welfare

Animal testing is a growing problem throughout Australia and the world. Although it has its benefits there are more negative reasons than positive. When people are testing on animals it results in the generation of chemical waste, which if not disposed of correctly it has long term impacts on the environmental landscapes and feature like the water and soil. The impact it is having on the animals' lives, our live and the globe will only be growing larger and larger if no action starts to happen. If we start a plan for action now than we can start a global change and help us and future generations have a better world to live in.
We therefore ask the House to start taking action against the use of animals for animal testing.
from 46 citizens (Petition No. EN6979)
Electoral Reform

Change the voting guidelines to allow under 18s who have a higher iq than me to vote. Cause what's the difference between them and me? We are both the same height, weight, but their smarter than me, have a higher iq than me, and have a larger capacity to learn than me, their iq will develop as they age mine will stay the same, I've been intellectually stunted, just cause I have more wrinkles and more organ damage and my organs have been aging and rotting longer doesn't mean I'm better or smarter than them. Just cause I've been awake longer than then doesn't make me superior.
They have better judgment than me, make better decisions than me, and should be allowed to vote. They fast learners and I am not.
We therefore ask the House to allow under 18s to vote
from five citizens (Petition No. EN6982)
Paid Parental Leave
There have been improvements in Parental leave in recent times, but Australia still significantly lags behind countries it would deem itself superior to in many other facets.

Children who have access to both parents in the first year of life, have been shown to reduce mortality rates, reduced the likelihood of medical conditions, improve the opportunity for bonding, breastfeeding, educational support and even help with parent to parent relationship balance.

From a macro-level, the economy can benefit with leave for both parents. Japan for example has the fourth largest economy in the world, yet allows both maternity and paternity for the first 12months of the child's life.

The challenge up to and beyond this is societal, but it seems logical to provide a benefit even if it doesn't get fully taken up. The option to parents to combine and take 6 months each for instance would support women re-entering the workforce and support men who want to take more hands on roles with their family's development.
We therefore ask the House to consider extending the parental leave period beyond the current threshold of 18+2 weeks.
Match the Japanese approach of 67% of base salary for 6 months and 50% from 6-12 months regardless of maternity or paternity.
Empower families to make the decision and trust that this will build a stronger future for Australia and healthier families for generations to come.
from 39 citizens (Petition No. EN6984)
Operation COVID-19 Assist

I am starting this petition to urge the government to honor all service members, particularly junior ranks, who participated in Operation COVID-19 Assist by issuing a dedicated medal. For three months, I and many others worked tirelessly in aged care homes and other critical settings, providing essential support during a national crisis. While we were initially promised medals, that commitment has since been withdrawn for junior ranks, even though high ranking officers have been awarded recognition.

This decision not only undermines our contributions but also highlights the inequities within the military awards system. Junior ranks were at the forefront, performing challenging, high-risk tasks in vulnerable environments. Despite this, the government has refused to issue the National Emergency Medal (NEM) or any equivalent recognition for our efforts. This decision is profoundly unfair and sends a disheartening message that the work of junior ranks is undervalued.

Medals are more than just decorations; they symbolize gratitude, respect, and the acknowledgment of service. It is unacceptable that only high ranking officers receive such recognition while junior ranks, who played an equally critical role, are overlooked.

This petition seeks to call on the government to issue a medal specifically for those who served during Operation COVID-19 Assist. Fair recognition should not depend on rank. All who contributed during this operation deserve equal acknowledgment for their dedication and sacrifice.
We therefore ask the House to ensure the government issues a medal recognizing all ranks for their contributions during Operation COVID-19 Assist, addressing inequities in the current awards system.
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN6997)
Human Rights: Afghanistan
Restore Girls' Education in Afghanistan

We therefore ask the House to I am writing to express my deep concern about the Taliban's ban on girls' education in Afghanistan. The Taliban's ban on girls' education is a blatant violation of human rights and international law. This is having a devastating impact on the lives of Afghan girls and women.
I urge the Australian Parliament to take immediate action to support the restoration of girls' education in Afghanistan. This includes:
Furthermore, we condemn the Taliban's efforts to indoctrinate children with extremist ideology, which is a form of psychological abuse and a threat to global security.
I respectfully request that the Australian Parliament consider this matter and take concrete actions to support the rights of Afghan girls and women to education.
I would like to start an e-petition on this issue, and I request that the Parliament consider the following petition:
Petition Request:
Title: Restore Girls' Education in Afghanistan To the Honourable Members of the Australian Parliament,
We, the undersigned, urge the Australian Government to take immediate action to support the restoration of girls' education in Afghanistan.
Publicly condemn the Taliban's ban on girls' education and call for its immediate reversal.

Encourage the International Criminal Court (ICC) to investigate the Taliban's crimes against humanity, including the denial of education to girls and the indoctrination of children with extremist ideology.
We believe that education is a fundamental human right, and that all girls and women should have access to education without fear of persecution or discrimination.
Thank you for considering our petition.
from 100 citizens (Petition No. EN6998)
Cybersafety

The psychological effects that social media is having on society is ripping our world apart in many areas of crime, suicide, hatred, gangs, addictions, depression, terrorism, brain washing and so much more. We are experiencing the damage right in front of our faces. Day in and day out we put our future generations at high risk of living in a world of hate, torture, mental health issue, psychological issue, self esteem issues, and no1 is doing anything about it because of the buisness's that profit having such a big influence over our economy.
Money is more important then our kids psychological state and future
We therefore ask the House to totally stop any access to social media platforms for humans under 16 years of age
from seven citizens (Petition No. EN6999)
Insurance Industry
Insurance has become too unaffordable, as a result many home owners are breaking their mortgage contracts etc.

We therefore ask the House to pass legislation to provide free govt insurance cover (no conditions attached) to every occupied house in Australia, (regardless of family incomes). We need a basic insurance safety net so every home is protected regardless.
from 27 citizens (Petition No. EN7000)
Sydney Jewish Museum

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, are deeply concerned about the recent allocation of $8.5 million to the Sydney Jewish Museum. Given that the Jewish population in Australia constitutes less than 0.5%, approximately 91,000 people, such a disproportionate allocation raises serious questions about the equitable distribution of public funds. This level of funding appears excessive when compared to the size and needs of the broader Australian population.

Recent diplomatic pressures and high-profile international criticism may have unduly influenced this decision, creating the perception of external interference. Public funds must be allocated fairly and transparently, without favouritism toward any single community. Significant investment in such a small population risks dividing Australians and undermines trust in the government's commitment to equality.

This allocation highlights ongoing concerns about government spending favouring smaller groups while larger communities, such as Catholic Australians— who constitute nearly 20% of the population—are often overlooked for similar targeted support. Ensuring proportionality in public spending is essential to fostering inclusivity and trust across Australia's diverse communities.

We therefore ask the House to review the allocation of $8.5 million to the Sydney Jewish Museum and ensure that future funding decisions are made with greater transparency, fairness, and equity. We further request that the House consider measures to establish clearer guidelines for public funding allocations to prevent perceptions of undue influence and to reflect the diverse needs of Australia's cultural and faith-based communities.
from 30 citizens (Petition No. EN7004)
Australian Flags

Peter Dutton has said that he will not stand with the three flags, Aboriginal, Australian and Torres Straight Islanders, saying it's divisive. However, Australian citizens wish to stand united and show respect to all three. We, the undersigned, respectfully request that a ruling be made to continue to display all three flags.
We therefore ask the House to make a definitive ruling to keep all three flags displayed, including the Sydney Harbour bridge and anywhere else the flags are displayed.
from 145 citizens (Petition No. EN7005)
Nuclear Energy

We call on the Australian Government to explore the integration of nuclear power and sustainable manufacturing practices by enabling the use of seawater for cooling nuclear power plants and repurposing the resulting brine to produce sea salt. This innovative approach would:
Maximize resource efficiency by utilizing byproducts of nuclear power for commercial applications.
Foster economic growth through job creation in both energy and food production industries.
Promote sustainability by reducing waste and supporting a circular economy.
Decrease transportation costs and carbon footprint by situating manufacturing facilities near power plants.

We propose a pilot project to co-locate a nuclear power plant with a sea salt production facility and a food manufacturing plant (e.g., a chip factory). This initiative would serve as a model for sustainable industrial practices, contributing to economic growth while addressing environmental challenges.
Your support is crucial to champion innovative, eco- friendly solutions that balance Australia's energy needs with long-term sustainability goals.

We therefore ask the House to support a feasibility study and pilot program for integrating nuclear power with sustainable sea salt production. This initiative would explore the use of seawater cooling in nuclear plants and the economic benefits of repurposing brine for commercial food production.
from 20 citizens (Petition No. EN7007)
Bangladesh

Shri Chinmoy Krishna Das Brahmachari (aka Chinmoy Prabhu), the 39-year-old Hindu monk, President of Pundarik Dham, and spokesperson for the Bangladesh Sammilita Sanatani Jagran Jote, rose to prominence for his outspoken protests when Hindus and their temples came under fierce attacks in Bangladesh, as the most others were suppressed and silenced. Unfortunately, his courage made him a target. On 25 November, Chinmoy Prabhu was detained at Dhaka Airport without identification or a warrant and later transferred to the Detective Branch. He was denied bail in the court on the following day. He faces baseless charges of "disrespecting the national flag," which have been widely discredited. Yet, Chinmoy Prabhu's legal rights were repeatedly violated—lawyers threatened, cases fabricated, and no legal representation allowed at his bail hearings. This is a clear violation of human rights.
This also constitutes a gross violation of the citizen's rights enshrined in Bangladesh's Constitution.

We therefore ask the House to engage diplomatically with Bangladesh to urge Chinmoy Prabhu's release, demand accountability for these human rights violations, and advocate for the protection of all human rights defenders in Bangladesh.
from 1,143 citizens (Petition No. EN7008)
Donations to Political Parties
We believe that democracy cannot function freely whilst the influence of corporate bodies over political parties remains.
We therefore ask the House to place a ban on all forms of donations from corporate bodies to politicians, political parties or groups.
Restrict the amount an individual can donate to $10k per year, and ensure total public transparency of donors names recipients names, and amounts.
from 6,676 citizens (Petition No. EN7009)
Cybersafety

Australia lacks a legislated, fixed minimum age for data consent, leaving children vulnerable to premature exposure to data collection and exploitation. Current laws under the Privacy Act 1988 rely on subjective assessments of a child's capacity to consent, creating inconsistencies and insufficient protections.

Tech companies, such as Google, allow children as young as 13 to independently manage their accounts, opting out of parental supervision. This exposes them to targeted advertising, inappropriate content, and data exploitation without adequate safeguards. Research shows children under 16 lack the cognitive maturity to fully understand the long-term consequences of sharing personal data.
Many countries, including those in the European Union, enforce a minimum age of 16 for data consent under the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).
Australia must align with these global standards to ensure the safety and privacy of its youth.
We therefore ask the House to :
Amend the Privacy Act 1988 to establish a legislated minimum age of 16 for consent to the collection, use, and disclosure of personal data.
Require parental consent for individuals under 16, with robust verification mechanisms.
Introduce meaningful penalties for companies that fail to protect children's privacy.

Protecting young Australians online is a critical issue. Stronger legislation will ensure their mental well-being and digital safety while fostering trust in Australia's commitment to safeguarding children's rights in the digital age.
from 12 citizens (Petition No. EN7010)
Menopause and Perimenopause

The long-running shortage of oestrogen and combination oestrogen-progesterone patches has been distressing and debilitating for Australian women of various ages who rely on the medicine to treat a range of menopausal symptoms such as anxiety, memory loss, mood swings, disturbed sleep, joint pain and post cancer treatment for early onset menopause. Request:
We therefore ask the House to increase domestic manufacture, and invest in supply chains to make sure Australia receives the medicines we need.
from 88 citizens (Petition No. EN7012)
Human Rights: Kurdish People

The Kurdish people, numbering over 40 million, represent one of the largest stateless nations in the world. Despite their cultural identity, historical heritage, and significant contributions to regional stability, they have faced decades of marginalization and conflict.

Kurdistan, as a homeland for the Kurdish people, has demonstrated a strong commitment to democratic principles, equality, and the fight against terrorism, particularly during the war against ISIS. The Kurdish people have sacrificed greatly for peace, security, and human rights in the Middle East.

Recognition of Kurdistan as an independent state would acknowledge the Kurdish people's right to self- determination, as outlined in international human rights conventions. It would also affirm Australia's role as a leader in supporting oppressed peoples, fostering stability in the Middle East, and strengthening diplomatic and economic partnerships.

We therefore ask the House to formally recognize Kurdistan as an independent and sovereign state and advocate for its recognition within the international community. By doing so, Australia will contribute to justice, peace, and the self-determination of the Kurdish people while fostering stronger bilateral ties with the Kurdistan Region.
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN7014)
Ukraine
The Australian Government is spending millions of dollars of taxpayers money to assist Ukraine. This money should be used in Australia, as per what tax payers want, not what the government chooses.
We therefore ask the House to fully withdraw from Ukraine and to stop using tax payers money to assist Ukraine.
from 24 citizens (Petition No. EN7016)

subdebateinfo.title: Universities: Financial Support for Postgraduate Students

p.span: Universities: Financial Support for Postgraduate Students

Currently, mainstream Doctorate studies and all Masters by research programs are not approved courses for Youth Allowance or Austudy. Therefore, students conducting important and impactful research are not eligible for financial assistance.

Full-time research students are required to dedicate 40+ hours per week to research, in addition to writing, data analysis, and administrative tasks. This intensive workload leaves little to no time for job applications or part-time work to support themselves financially.

Research students play a critical role in driving innovation, advancing knowledge, and solving real- world problems across various fields. Despite their contributions to society and the economy, they face significant financial hardship due to the lack of government support.

It is essential to recognize and address this gap by approving Doctorate and Masters by research programs for Youth Allowance and Austudy. Supporting research students means investing in Australia's future.
We therefore ask the House to approve research students for Youth Allowance and Austudy.
from 66 citizens (Petition No. EN7022)
Australia Day

Every year Australia Day causes angst and division throughout the Australian community. Instead of celebrating it on the 26th January we could change it to the third Monday in January. The date will change every year so the day isn't connected to any political or historical events. Australia Day means many things to different people and removing any political connection can allow all communities to rejoice in celebrating what Australia Day means to them personally. No one misses out on a public holiday and the focus will purely be on celebrating what it means to be Australian to you. This way we can truly celebrate the day not the date.
We therefore ask the House to consider changing the public holiday from 26th January to the third Monday of January every year.
from 141 citizens (Petition No. EN7023)
Animal Welfare: Online Safety

residents of australia draws to the attention of the House the continuing explosion of online torture of animals on social media platforms which has a devastating effect on the mental health of children and other internet users. Social media sites must not be used as platforms to promote the sadistic and harrowing actions of some deeply depraved internet users. Current laws are weak with the failure to comply with a blocking or removal notice punishable by fines of up to $156,500 for an individual and $782,500 for a corporation).

We therefore ask the House to increase protection for animals against online torture and protection for Internet users by upgrading current laws to be in line with those offered by the UK under the Online Safety Bill. We ask the House to enforce tougher new laws for social media platforms to proactively remove illegal activity or face fines of up to 35 million dollars or 10% of global income for companies, in line with UK laws and to fine individuals $300,000. We ask that even if the activity takes place outside of Australia but is seen by users in Australia that tech companies will be made to take it down as part of a zero tolerance policy with increased fines. We ask for a taskforce be deployed to monitor online torturers to fast track the implementation of this law and to educate the public how to report in the face of increasing online animal torture.
from 32 citizens (Petition No. EN7025)
Cybersafety

Several experts have released advice to the government of the risks of the under-16s social media ban and why it will damage the mental health of young people because it disconnects young people from family and friends and the world. This ban denies young people the freedom to have free speech and denies their freedom to the outside world.
We therefore ask the House to consider the advice from several experts and the human rights Commission on the under-16s social media ban and to change the age from 16 to 14
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN7029)
Asbestos
1 in 3 Australian homes still contain asbestos. Asbestos poses a serious health risks such as cancer and asbestosis. Between 700 and 800 people are diagnosed with mesothelioma in Australia each year.
The Australian Government is now up to Phase Three of the Asbestos National Strategic Plan (2024—2030) which focuses on proactive asbestos removal.

However, only owners of rental and commercial properties are able to claim tax concessions for testing, removal and replacement of asbestos containing materials in their properties (TR 2020/2). This means owner-occupiers are unable to access the same level of financial support to remove asbestos from their homes.
We therefore ask the House to
Immediately extend the asbestos removal and replacement tax deductions that are currently available only to owners of commercial and rental properties to all homeowners (owner-occupiers).
Investigate the feasibility of a grant scheme/ further tax concessions for all owners of homes with asbestos containing material to remove and replace asbestos containing materials from their homes.
from 775 citizens (Petition No. EN7030)
Broadband

The nbn FULL FIBRE FOR STRATA-MANAGED BUILDINGS program is unfair and short sighted and blatantly discriminates against people renting by removing their agency. Houses in an FTTP upgrade area are offered a "free" upgrade for a nominal plan commitment. If there are.4+ dwellings on a block of land the only upgrade path is the nbn FULL FIBRE FOR STRATA-MANAGED BUILDINGS program.

This program forces all premesis to be upgraded at once and requires the owner or strata to pay a fee for each premises (listed as $275 per premises but often more) regardless of whether or not they have a current FTTN connection or if they want to upgrade to FTTP. The owner/strata then makes the application to NBNCo who then come and provide a quote—in many cases significantly more than $275 per premises—which has resulted in some owners and strata deciding not to proceed.

In the event they agree—given the current rental shortage—these costs will very likely be passed on as rent increases to all tenants, even those without an FTTN connection and those who don't want to upgrade to FTTP.
The cost of maintaining the FTTN network rises every year while revenue from it is capped and for those stuck on FTTN alternatives like Starlink are more enticing every day.
We therefore ask the House to ensure renters have the opportunities to upgrade to high speed FTTP as their neighbours do.
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN7032)
Pensions and Benefits
Centrelink banning leaves the homeless without money for food. Then reliant on Non for Profit support groups for food and washing.
We therefore ask the House to make it Australian legislation to not ban Ceñtrelink unless in jail.
Employment Agencies are to suggest counselling and other support compliance groups.
from 17 citizens (Petition No. EN7035)
Cybersafety
There is and increase of explicit material being posted across TikTok and other social media's. Theses media's are used primarily by people under the age of 18. We need to take a stand.
We therefore ask the House to enforce more control over the social media's.
from eight citizens (Petition No. EN7036)
International Students

Inclusivity and Diversity: Allowing students over 35 to apply for the post-graduate visa promotes inclusivity and diversity within the academic community. Many individuals seek to further their education later in life, and this change would support their aspirations.

Economic Benefits: Mature students often bring a wealth of professional experience and skills that can contribute significantly to the Australian economy. By enabling them to stay and work in Australia after completing their studies, the country can benefit from their expertise.

Addressing Skills Shortages: Australia faces skills shortages in various sectors. Allowing older students to apply for the post-graduate visa can help address these shortages by retaining skilled graduates who are ready to enter the workforce.
Encouraging Lifelong Learning: This change would encourage lifelong learning and professional development, aligning with global trends and the evolving nature of the workforce.
We therefore ask the House to consider this petition and make the necessary amendments to support the educational and professional goals of students over 35.
from 33 citizens (Petition No. EN7039)
Artificial Intelligence

Recently, there has been an increasing rise of AI use in creative based industries, including acting, filmmaking, art, music and more. Those apart of these industries have henceforth felt concern and worry in regards to this expansion, as we fear that their craft could be rendered obsolete and force them out of employment, and additionally could see a great facet of Australia as a whole scrubbed away in favor of tasteless and poorly crafted content.
We therefore ask the House to protect these areas of employment by banning any usage of AI in creative industries to protect those who work in them and the Australian creative scene at large.
from 50 citizens (Petition No. EN7040)
Workplace Safety: Second-hand Smoke

Exposure to secondhand smoke (SHS) has been consistently identified as a public health hazard and cause of disease for many hospitality workers ex: (non smokers hospitality employees in the casino gaming areas in Australia). As a hospitality employees, and a non smoker, we need to support the SHS of the customers at work inside the gaming area.

We therefore ask the House to find a way that can help with the smoke free work environment for non smoking employees in the casino gaming areas, or to create designated smoking rooms only for the smoking customers, prior to enter the gaming room.
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN7045)
Family Law
The current child support system is outdated and unfair. The whole system needs to be updated and to be made fair.
Remove overtime hours from child support assessment
Cap on child support per child.
If a parent cannot see their children why should they have to pay child support.
Stop parental alienation
Just to name a few things that need addressing. These issues are a huge contributor to suicide and domestic violence.
I believe that addressing the outdated and toxic system that is currently in place will save lives.
We therefore ask the House to review and updated the current child support system.
from 232 citizens (Petition No. EN7048)
1st Armoured Regiment

In its 75th year, 1st Armoured Regiment, the Army's senior combat unit, has been relegated to a non- combat role; essentially removing it from the Order of Battle. Rather than crewing tanks to destroy the enemy and provide intimate fire support to infantry … it will be tasked with testing new technologies. The sole rationale for this is to minimise the cost of relocating personnel to Townsville (from Adelaide).

This is at odds with the fact that it is service and regimental pride that lies at the heart of an Army's fighting spirit. It is especially heart-breaking to veterans when the loss of heritage and tradition established during the unit's service since 1949, can so easily be avoided.

Rather than 2nd Cavalry Regiment in Townsville commanding two tank and two reconnaissance squadrons, 1st Armoured Regiment could command the two tank squadrons. No new facilities would be required. Given that morale is part of the Army's combat power, any cost would be offset by the morale boost achieved.

We therefore ask the House to urge the Defence Minister, Richard Marles, to reinstate 1st Armoured Regiment as the nation's tank regiment, overturning the Department of Defence's decision to remove the Royal Australian Armoured Corps' oldest and most decorated regular army unit from the ORBAT.
We seek this so as to honour the service and sacrifice of tank crews during the past 75 years, creating an inspirational legacy worthy of being passed on to those serving today.
from 176 citizens (Petition No. EN7051)
Service Industry

Increasingly, the service industry is attempting to introduce USA-style tipping (gratuity) into Australia. This may be in the form of "default gratuity" that you need to ask to have removed, "optional gratuity" where the customer must select a percentage tip (even if zero is an option), or similar.

In Australia, we expect business to fairly compensate their workers, and for the cost to do so to be included in the purchase price for the goods or services. It is not the responsibility of the customer to decide how much compensation a worker should receive by paying gratuity, nor is it the responsibility of the worker to need to guilt the customer in order to receive their salary.

We therefore ask the House to forbid businesses operating in Australia from having "default" or "optional" gratuity, or from having any other "tip"-like options that require customer intervention to avoid and/or are non-zero by default.
from 124 citizens (Petition No. EN7052)
Israel: Hilltop Youth
We, a group of concerned citizens of Australia, respectfully urge the House to consider a discussion on the removal of sanctions imposed on the seven members of the Israeli Hilltop Youth.

These young individuals have faced significant scrutiny and, we believe, have been disproportionately affected by these sanctions. We acknowledge that Israel has a robust and independent legal system capable of addressing any concerns regarding their actions based on available evidence.
Interfering with their due process may not be conducive to fostering strong ties with our allies in Israel.
Furthermore, a lack of comprehensive understanding of the complexities on the ground can lead to misunderstandings within our community and may contribute to a distorted narrative in media reporting.
We therefore ask the House to remove these sanctions to promote fairness and strengthen our diplomatic relations.
Thank you for your attention to this matter.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN7054)
Australian Constitution

State Governments have played a key pivotal role in Australian history over our first 100 years of federation. However as a nation we have not evolved and in 2025 still operate under a colonial model of governance.

With concern to the current cost of living pressures, multiple layers of legislation, cost duplication of service delivery as well as inconsistent rules it makes sense to consolidate a level of governance as a country.
We therefore ask the House to consider holding a referendum to:

Abolishing/Sunsetting the state government layer under the constitution and transfer law making authority and service delivery management for all states and territories to the federal government. Or alternatively as an intermediary step removing one of the house for each state similar to the Queensland model.
Resulting implications:
Increase council management of services and scope of delivery with councils reporting line direct to the federal government.
Consolidation and review of commonwealth monies spending and laws to provide a consistent approach across all states and territories.
from 39 citizens (Petition No. EN7059)
Australian Currency
Steve Irwin is a national treasure and needs to be represented more. The $5 note would be a perfect way to honour him.
We therefore ask the House to remove the queen from the $5 note and put a true blue Aussie on there to represent us.
from 52 citizens (Petition No. EN7063)
Biosecurity

Australia is home to many unique animals, including marsupials, monotremes, and arthropods, including threatened species of butterflies and other native species. Australia is considered malaria-free and Australia has one of the lowest infant mortality rates in the world.

Any company or organisation who releases any Genetically modified insect or animal, or any insect or animal which is used to carry any medical treatment or has the intent of releasing any GMO or Lab DNA modified insect or animal into Australia, without the express will of the people, agreed to by a National Referendum for each application, should be an offense pursuant of Subdivision A of 307 of the Criminal Code (Cth)
