We therefore ask the House to introduce into law the offence of: Attempting to or the deliberate release of any GMO or Lab DNA modified insect or animal into Australia shall be an offence pursuant of Subdivision A of 307 of the Criminal Code (Cth) and such an offence involving release of any quantity of GMO or Laboratory DNA modified insect or animal carries a maximum penalty of life imprisonment, and carries a minimum penalty of 25 years imprisonment.
from 77 citizens (Petition No. EN7068)
Cybersafety

Our democracy is under siege, and the culprit is lurking in our pockets. X, formerly known as Twitter, has become a breeding ground for mis and disinformation, extremism, and foreign interference. It's time we take a stand against this digital menace.

From amplifying conspiracy theories to reinstating banned accounts spewing hate, X has shown a blatant disregard for our online safety and the integrity of democratic processes. The platform's algorithms are designed to feed us a toxic diet of falsehoods, while its owner openly propagates far-right ideologies.

Remember the Voice referendum? X played a significant role in spreading misinformation that contributed to its failure. With the federal election on the horizon, we can't afford to let it be bought by billionaires the same way Elon Musk bought the US election.

Brazil has already taken the bold step of banning X. It's time for Australia to follow suit. Sign this petition to urge the government to implement an Australia-wide ban of X and other socially corrosive platforms that knowingly spread hate, mis and disinformation, facilitate bullying, and the radicalisation of users under the guise of free speech.
Take action to protect Australia from these devious networks who gain either financially or politically by manufacturing societal division. Your voice matters! Request:
We therefore ask the House to implement an Australia- wide ban of the social media platform X (formerly Twitter).
from 242 citizens (Petition No. EN7075)
Pensions and Benefits

Australians deserve dignity, safety, and independence. Yet the current welfare system ties financial support to a partner's income, leaving many struggling to survive or trapped in unsafe relationships.
Under current rules, payments like the Disability Support Pension (DSP) are reduced when a partner earns over $372 per fortnight and cease entirely at
$1,516.40. This policy assumes all relationships are safe and equitable, but for many, this is not the case.
The impact is severe:
46% of disabled Australians cannot work and rely solely on DSP.
DSP pays just $24,636 annually, far below the average income of $55,310.
Financial dependence increases vulnerability to economic abuse, trapping individuals in unsafe situations.

One supporter shared how Centrelink complications forced her to return to work during cancer treatment because her husband's income disqualified her from adequate financial support under JobSeeker. Despite her health struggles, she had no choice but to risk her recovery to survive.

The government's National Plan to End Violence Against Women and Children emphasises financial independence as a pathway to safety. Yet these rules undermine that goal, leaving vulnerable Australians without the resources to escape hardship or abuse.

We therefore ask the House to abolish partner income tests across all welfare payments, raise DSP rates to meet basic living costs, and implement safeguards to protect welfare recipients from economic abuse.
These reforms are essential for dignity, safety, and equality for all Australians.
from 19,026 citizens (Petition No. EN7076)
Nuclear Energy

We face an urgent need to phase out electricity production powered by fossil fuels. Renewable energy is unable to provide reliable base load power. CSIRO estimates that in 2050 13% of electricity will still be generated by gas. The CO2 produced will be captured and stored. Hence net zero not real zero. The Canadian CANDU reactors have been operating safely and reliably for many years. The Koreans were able to build the Wolsong-3 reactor in only four years. A total of seven CANDU reactors built between 1996 and 2007 were built within budget without any cost blowout. The CANDU reactor runs on unenriched uranium and does not pose a proliferation risk. The construction costs can be met by a levy on coal and gas exports. A carbon solution levy could raise 100 billion dollars in its first year according to one study. The polluters should pay so it won't cost the taxpayer a cent. This part of the electricity network will be owned by the government and with capital costs eliminated will provide very cheap electricity.
We therefore ask the House to to
Start replacing all coal fired power stations right now with CANDU nuclear power stations
Finance their construction with a levy on all coal and gas exports.
Complete this process by 2035.
from 29 citizens (Petition No. EN7078)
Housing

The 491 visa holders are skilled migrants on a pathway to permanent residency in Australia. They contribute to regional communities by addressing labour shortages and driving economic growth. Treated as tax residents, they pay taxes at the same rates as citizens and are eligible for benefits such as Medicare, reflecting their integration into Australian society.

However, when purchasing a home, 491 visa holders face significant financial barriers. Classified as foreign residents, they are excluded from first-home buyer benefits and are subject to high Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) fees, additional stamp duties, and stricter deposit requirements from banks.

These challenges impose undue strain on individuals and families working to build stable futures in Australia and contradict the intent of the 491visa program, which aims to support skilled migrants in settling and contributing to regional areas.

We request the House to consider the above and include 491 visa holders in the benefits available to first-home buyers. Extending these benefits will reduce financial pressures, facilitate their settlement journey, and encourage long-term stability. Recognizing their contributions aligns with the principles of fairness and inclusivity, reinforcing Australia's commitment to supporting skilled migrants who enrich its economy and communities.

We therefore ask the House to include holders of the Subclass 491 visa in the benefits and concessions provided to first-home buyers in Australia, including exemptions or reductions in Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) fees, additional stamp duties, and eligibility for government-supported schemes such as reduced deposit requirements.
from 277 citizens (Petition No. EN7079)
Banking and Financial Services

This petition of concerned Australian citizens draws the attention of the House to the lack of transparency surrounding credit card surcharges. Currently, credit card surcharges are not uniformly disclosed in a manner that allows cardholders to easily understand how much they are spending on these fees. This lack of transparency may lead to financial strain for individuals and inhibits informed decision-making when managing personal finances.
We therefore ask the House to:
Mandate the disclosure of credit card surcharges on monthly statements: Require credit card issuers to provide a clear total of surcharges incurred during the statement period.

Ensure consistent and standardised reporting: Develop guidelines for the uniform presentation of surcharge information across all credit card statements, making it easy for consumers to identify and understand.

Improve consumer awareness and financial literacy: Encourage credit card issuers to include explanatory notes about surcharges, helping cardholders understand how these fees are calculated and the circumstances under which they apply.

By implementing these measures, Australian consumers will be empowered with the knowledge to make informed decisions about their credit card usage, reduce unnecessary expenses, and better manage their personal finances.
We therefore ask the House to take action on this matter.
from 44 citizens (Petition No. EN7085)
Numurkah: Government Services

Numurkah faces challenges due to limited access to services, including public transport. A Services Australia kiosk in Numurkah would greatly benefit the community by providing essential government services locally. Access to government services is crucial for residents in need of assistance with Centrelink, Medicare, or other government-related matters.

Without a local kiosk, residents have to travel to access these services, causing inconvenience and financial strain, especially for those with limited mobility or financial resources. Numurkah's limited public transport exacerbates the issue, making it difficult for residents to reach nearby towns with Services Australia kiosks. This lack of accessibility disproportionately affects vulnerable populations such as the elderly, people with disabilities, and low-income families who rely on these services A Services Australia kiosk in Numurkah would improve accessibility and promote community engagement and empowerment. It would encourage residents to take advantage of available government support programs, fostering inclusion and support within the community. Considering that other community houses in the Moira Shire have kiosks, it highlights the disparity faced by Numurkah residents.

Equal access to essential services is a fundamental right, and establishing a kiosk in Numurkah would align with the government's commitment to ensuring equitable access to services for all Australians, regardless of their location. A Services Australia kiosk in Numurkah will provide services conveniently and equitably.

We therefore ask the House to approve the establishment of a Services Australia kiosk in Numurkah to address the challenges posed by limited public transport and to ensure that all residents have access to vital government services.
from 198 citizens (Petition No. PN0634)
Cobar: Government Services

The town of Cobar is remotely located in far west New South Wales. There have been no Centrelink and Medicare customer services in Cobar for many years, and customers are forced to travel to Dubbo or Bourke to access face-to-face customer assistance. The large number of aged persons in Cobar (and the surrounding area) are unable to make these trips and as a result are severely disadvantaged. Other Centrelink and Medicare customers (disabled and unemployed) are similarly disadvantaged by the lack of service delivery in Cobar. Request

We therefore ask the House to in the next Budget cycle, to delegate dedicated Centrelink and Medicare customer service hours (on a face-to-face basis) in Cobar on a regular basis (at least 2/3 days per week).
from 443 citizens (Petition No. PN0635)
Middle East

We thank the Australian Government for its restoration of aid to the UN Relief and Works Agency and for voting to recognise Palestine as qualified to join the United Nations. In the name of peace, we ask that it take further steps to support the safety, human rights and self-determination of the Palestinian people.
We therefore ask the House to call upon the Australian government to:
Recognise Palestine as a full UN member state;
Advocate for an immediate ceasefire with the deployment throughout Palestine of international peace-keeping and reconstruction forces;
Advocate for independent negotiations to secure the release of the Israeli hostages held by Hamas and the more than 9000 Palestinians held by in Israel;
Ban the export of weapons and military components to Israel from Australia, both directly and through third countries;
Expel the Israeli Ambassador if Israel continues its assault on Gaza.
from 1,188 citizens (Petition No. PN0637)
Cost of Living: Education
Dear sir,
There are so many struggling families in australia at the present moment, families are already struggling to put meals on the table for their kids and pay the bills.
Now the stress of getting the kids back to school with all the items they need, not mentioning the rise in prices of the products.

It is unfair that families have this stress as it is your government that made it mandatory to attend school, there needs to be more support for helping acheive that requirement. Its not fair on families to have this stress added on top of everyday stresses we all have in our lives.
More needs to be done
Kind regards
Sallie hammond
( member of the public)
We therefore ask the House to consider giving a helping hand to families
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN7125)
Skilled Migration

Thousands of Subclass 491 Skilled Work Regional Visa applicants face distress due to prolonged processing delays, breaking the promises made during the visa's introduction. The extended timelines significantly impact the mental health, professional growth, and well-being of skilled migrants actively contributing to regional Australia. The 491 visa was introduced with the assurance of faster processing and a clear pathway to permanent residency. However, current timelines suggest a 5-7 year wait for eligibility for the Subclass 191 Permanent Residence Visa, plus another 2 years for government benefits. This prolonged uncertainty imposes emotional strain, anxiety, and financial hardship on applicants who uprooted their lives in good faith to support Australia's regional development.

Restrictions preventing full use of their skills further compound these challenges. The delays undermine the visa's core purpose of addressing regional skill shortages and risk eroding trust in Australia's immigration system. If not resolved, Australia may lose the goodwill and contributions of thousands of skilled migrants vital to regional growth.
We therefore ask the House to urge the Department of Home Affairs to:
Prioritise Subclass 191 visa processing to reduce backlogs.
Increase transparency with realistic processing timelines.
Streamline the pathway to permanent residency.
Provide mental health support for affected onshore applicants. Skilled migrants have invested in Australia's future.

The government must honour its commitments and ensure a fair, efficient visa process to restore trust and support these individuals and families wo are awaiting for grants for their loved ones to live together in mentally sound environment.
from 518 citizens (Petition No. EN7127)
International Students

Unethical Blackbox of an Expensive Australia Student Visa for research students with unjustifiable delays and no explanation jeopardises the lives, careers, and Australia's future as a knowledge-based economy.

Extraordinary visa processing time, non-transparent process and unresponsiveness for PhD applicants of visa subclass 500 has significantly undermined researchers' career, Australia's Economy and research Flourishment. While some recent applications are being finalised in short times, many applications lodged very long ago (even more than one year ago) remain unfinalized.
Whether applications from engineering students are being processed or not just thrown away is really doubtful.

We therefore ask the House to Provide Timely Decisions: Establish clear deadlines for visa processing, with updates provided regularly, even if the decision is a rejection.Give decision within respectful time even if you have to reject, So applicants can look for other options.
Clear the backlog: Please announce decision on VISAs which are waiting for more than 4 months.

Enhance Transparency and Time-bound decisions: Allow applicants to track the status of security checks and other assessments. Enforce a deadline to complete the security checks in respect of applicants' life, skills, and money that he paid.
from 15 citizens (Petition No. EN7129)
Bill of Rights
Citizens of Australia need a bill of rights to protect them.

We therefore ask the House to start an inquiry into a bill of rights to protect the Australia citizens. Rights that no council or state governments can break. Rights that protect its citizens . From unjust means .
Example. Rights to stop trespassing on private property.right to bear arms. Right to self defense without fear of consequences
Right to travel . Right to a home above foreign people.right to employment above foreign people. Citizens deserve to feel safe.
from 51 citizens (Petition No. EN7131)
Banking and Financial Services
86400 was only available as an app. There was no website or phone banking. When the app broke there was no access to banking
digital banks have no branches they must ensure there is sufficient access to dispense cash through cash machines, Australia Post and retailers
Ubank demanded all customers download their app for KYC survey threatening suspending accounts rather providing webform online
Macquarie is forcing customers to app with by drastically reducing payment limits online after a period of inflation.

Banks force people to be continuously connected and tracked with apps to authorise transactions. There should be minimum of multifactor alternatives to ensure accounts are not locked out e.g. phone, SMS, MMS, secure SMS, security tokens.
Provide a channel that can be physically secured. Whilst an app may have enhanced security; mobile phone is not physically secure like PC or landline locked securely in house
We therefore ask the House to provide minimum standards for digital banking that ensure:
Ubiquitous access, including internet and phone options for all functions.
Sufficient access to cash via third parties like cash machines, Australia Post and retailers
Provide all services through every channel.
Ensure banking services are always available by providing alternative support channels.
Provide a consistent service across all channels.
Provide a minimum number of alternative multi- factor authentication methods that ensure accounts are always accessible.
Provide a channel that can be physically secured in the home independent of mobile solutions
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN7132)
Grocery Prices
Prices in shops. Specials and different in price on shelf and checkout
We therefore ask the House to investigate shop pricing system of shops like Cole's Woolworths Aldi. And others…. The price advertised compared to special.
Advertisement then. Checkouts.
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN7133)
Skilled Migration
The 191 visa was introduced as fast processed visa back in 2019.
Claire O'Neil said (and was right by saying it) that "the immigration system is broken", and it still be really unfair for some skilled migrants these days.

The current 191 visa processing time is 10 months. It used to be up to 2 months, which was acceptable at the time. Seeing this processing time increasing every month is totally unacceptable. Some migrants which applied or are going to apply to the 191 visa have already been in Australia for around 10 years, with temporary visas, considered as foreigners by the Australian government, then with a 491 visa, which was sometimes granted 29 months after applying to it !!!

And now the same people have to face again this long wait, not really being able to live normal lives, because they can't get a mortgage or the work they are supposed to be doing because of their current visa restrictions… They are not eligible to get child subsidies, they're facing high school fees to universities.
We therefore ask the House to prioritise the 191 visa processing and make the hard working "provisional" workers proud to become Australian permanent resident, not tired !
from 103 citizens (Petition No. EN7134)

subdebateinfo.title: Human Rights: Gender and Sexual Orientation

p.span: Human Rights: Gender and Sexual Orientation

I urge the parliament to take immediate action to amend the regulations to include the United States of America as an applicable country for this visa and, crucially, to explicitly recognize sexual orientation and gender identity as valid grounds for seeking protection.

Currently, the Subclass 866 visa offers protection to individuals who have a well-founded fear of persecution in their home country. This vital pathway to safety is currently restricted to a specific list of countries, excluding the United States. This exclusion is deeply concerning, particularly given the increasingly hostile environment faced by some individuals within the US, including but not limited to the LGBTQIA+ community.

The rise in discriminatory legislation, hate speech, and violence targeting specific groups in the US, coupled with the weakening of legal protections for vulnerable populations, demonstrates that a genuine risk of persecution exists for some individuals. These individuals, particularly those from marginalized communities, may find themselves in situations where their safety and fundamental human rights are severely threatened.

These amendments would send a clear message that Australia stands with those who are oppressed and that we will not stand idly by while vulnerable individuals are persecuted. It would also align Australia's approach with the best practices of other nations in protecting LGBTQIA+ refugees and asylum seekers.

We therefore ask the House to Include the United States as an applicable country, and explicitly recognize sexual orientation and gender identity as grounds for protection, Australia can demonstrate a true commitment to human rights and global responsibility.
from 17 citizens (Petition No. EN7135)

subdebateinfo.title: International Relations: Australia and the United States of America

p.span: International Relations: Australia and the United States of America

The USA is previous times has been an ally against fascism. No longer since Trump became President of the USA. He admires and wishes to emulate dictators and fascist leaders around the world. He is no longer interested in being allies with democratic countries.

You can no longer use our alliance with the USA in previous wars, to excuse a continued alliance and access to our country. The current leader of the USA is no longer an ally or a protector of democracy.

We therefore ask the House to deport all US service people, shut down all US military bases and weapons systems. Dismantle all US intelligence services and hardware/software being used on Australian soil.
Australians will NOT support a Fascist leader of foreign heritage. We fought against Hitler and we will fight against Donald Trump, in support of our allies in the EU, Denmark, Panama etc.
from 29 citizens (Petition No. EN7136)
Middle East: Media Coverage

Many Australians are aware of the conflict in Isreal and Palestine. The human casualties in this conflict seems to be weighed far to heavily upon innocent Palestinian people. The balance of view in this conflict seems to subdue the outrageous actions by the Israeli Defence Force which can often be described as horrific. It is therefore essential that further scope and unbiased reporting on this matter by ABC news outlets exposing more of the harm done to the Palestinian people be reported.

We therefore ask the House to intervene with the sub- standard of balanced reporting and openly declare that the actions of the Israeli Defence Force may be concidered as inhumane and actions akin to genocide. The vast bombing of hospitals and schools are evidence of adhoc aggression by the Israeli forces and these issues must be exposed to stop the slaughter of innocent civillians and children. The ABC news broadcasts must be monitored st all times on this topic to ensure balanced and factual reporting continues after this ePetition is reviewed in Parliament.
It is also required to investigate who is the "gatekeeper" of this news content and their role be further reviewed as to their appropriat appointmen within the ABC news services.
Further more, a Senate Enquirey may be required to deal with this matter, as important as it is.
Thank you.
from 16 citizens (Petition No. EN7138)

subdebateinfo.title: International Relations: Australia and the United States of America

p.span: International Relations: Australia and the United States of America
Australia has a concerning reliance upon the United States which compromises both the safety of its citizens and the sovereignty of the nation.

The United States has elected a President that does not believe in the rule of law, social cohesion, the value of diversity and tolerance and exhibits a posture of isolationism and expansionism that is not in the best interest of Australia and its people.

We therefore ask the House to immediately pause all alliances, agreements and cooperation with the United States until Parliament is able to adequately assess whether our countries share values and that existing relationships between the nations are considered in the best interest of Australian citizens.
from 2,109 citizens (Petition No. EN7139)
Consumer Protection

We urge the Australian Parliament to take immediate legislative and regulatory action to protect land /home buyers from financial misconduct and enhance oversight of property sale process and transactions that involve instalment contracts, as well as financial institutions involved in lending.

The collapse of Qartaba Homes Pty Ltd has exposed significant gaps in consumer protection, leaving hundreds of Australian families financially devastated. Qartaba Homes sold residential land through instalment contracts, taking buyers' life savings and superannuation but wrongfully mortgaged the land to lenders without purchasers' consent. This led to $200 million in loans at interest rates as high as 26%, which Qartaba did not pay back, causing severe financial distress for the affected families. Hundreds of families across Australia have lost their life savings and lands as mortgagees are taking possession of the lands and selling them, while instalment purchasers helplessly watch the lands being sold which they had purchased many years ago and had paid the full price.

The liquidation of Qartaba Homes in October 2024 and ongoing investigations highlight systemic regulatory failures that allowed fraudulent practices and predatory lending to go unchecked. Urgent reforms are needed to prevent similar incidents and ensure justice for affected Australians.
We therefore ask the House to :
Strengthen consumer protection in property sales under instalment contracts, and coordinate among States to update their legislation related to such sales
Amend insolvency laws to prioritize consumer claims over institutional lenders involved in deceptive practices.
Enhance ASIC's capabilities for expedited actions and investigations into such misconduct.
from 1,550 citizens (Petition No. EN7142)
Education

religious god-preachers from all types of religions- groups, are illegally using god-religious artificial intelligence controlled by hypnosis-prayer, to create their never-lived (living image) of their god (into a living thing) which is now legally called out to be' fraud by deception.

We therefore ask the House to legislate this Australian Federal Education Bill: Amend our Federal Education ACT: Educate all Australian Children in all cultures and categories of gender, about anatomical changes to their body organisms over millions of years, the evolutionary process that created all Humankind; so for the future of Humanity we ask the Australian Federal Government to introduce one (Federal Human-evolution Education law) to hold authority over one (Compulsory Separate Federal Human-evolution Education Curriculum) in grades 1 to 12, for all Australian Students in all States and Territories to receive (Human-evolution Education).
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN7143)
Metaldehyde

Metaldehyde, a toxic chemical commonly used in slug and snail baits, poses significant environmental and health risks to humans and pets that warrant its ban in Australia. One of the primary concerns is its impact on non-target wildlife. When metaldehyde baits are used in gardens or agricultural settings, animals such as birds, amphibians, and native mammals can ingest the bait, leading to poisoning. As these creatures are often crucial to local ecosystems, the poisoning of such species can have long-lasting consequences on biodiversity.

In addition to wildlife, metaldehyde is a direct threat to pets, particularly dogs, which are attracted to the bait. The ingestion of even small amounts can be fatal, leading to symptoms such as vomiting, seizures, and in most cases death.

Metaldehyde also presents a danger to human health. While its direct toxicity to humans is less pronounced, accidental ingestion or inhalation of its dust can cause poisoning, particularly in children or those who handle the product without proper safety precautions.

Furthermore, safer, more sustainable alternatives to metaldehyde exist for pest control. These alternatives do not carry the same environmental and health risks, making the continued use of metaldehyde unnecessary. Banning its use in Australia would protect ecosystems, wildlife, and human health from its harmful effects.
We therefore ask the House to ban for sale and use all products containing metaldehyde
from 808 citizens (Petition No. EN7144)
Child Safety
To many children are left in hot vehicles due to not being dropped off to a child minding facility because parents have forgotten. To many children have died and there's a simple solution!
We therefore ask the House to make absentee phone calls mandatory for all facilities where children are present if prior notice of absence hasn't been given.
from 15 citizens (Petition No. EN7145)
Groundwater: Chemical Contamination

Australia is at risk of massive contamination of our Artesian Basins, the freshwater underground lakes across NT, QLD, NSW, SA, from oil and gas industry underground drilling. Our leading scientists tell governments, but they are ignored.
Stop approving new gas fields and pipelines.
Methane is a volatile and potent greenhouse gas.
Current gas production and Exports exceed Australia's international commitments to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
We therefore ask the House to Ban new oil and gas Fracking.

We ask the House to audit current oil and gas infrastructure and pipelines for leaks. This can now simply be done by Bureau of Meteorology analysis of satellite data across Australia and territorial waters.
from 95 citizens (Petition No. EN7146)
Environmental Conservation
Restrictions on Outdoor Activities:
The expansion of national parks has restricted cherished activities such as hiking and four-wheel driving etc, which promote health and well-being.
Lack of Consultation:
Decisions by the FNPW often lack adequate consultation with communities and stakeholders. An inclusive approach is essential for sustainable conservation.
Actions by a minority are often amplified by the media, leading to decisions that shut out the majority instead of managing the behavior constructively.
Transparency and Accountability:
We urge the FNPW and similar agencies to provide greater transparency about their; funding, decisions, and initiatives' impact.
Clear communication is crucial for building trust and ensuring effective conservation.
Closing parks doesn't solve offending behavior; education and management do.
Offenders should be managed, not the responsible majority excluded.
We therefore ask the House to Review and Amend Policies:
Review current policies related to national parks and protected areas to balance conservation with the rights of outdoor enthusiasts.
Enhanced Community Engagement:
Mandate the FNPW and relevant agencies to actively engage in meaningful consultation with local communities, outdoor enthusiasts, and stakeholders before implementing new initiatives.
Encourage collaboration and dialogue to find mutually beneficial solutions.
Increased Transparency:
Require the FNPW and relevant agencies to provide regular updates on their projects, funding sources, and outcomes.
Ensure information is easily accessible to the public.
By addressing these concerns, the government can foster a balanced approach to conservation that respects the rights of every Australian.
Immediate action is needed to preserve our natural environment for future generations without compromising healthy lifestyle choices and valued Australian outdoor traditions.
from 73 citizens (Petition No. EN7147)
National Diabetes Services Scheme

We request that the Australian Government amend the eligibility criteria of the National Diabetes Services Scheme (NDSS) to ensure that all individuals diagnosed with cystic fibrosis-related diabetes (CFRD) have equitable and lifelong access to essential diabetes management support. This includes subsidised access to blood glucose monitoring devices, insulin pumps, and continuous glucose monitoring systems, as well as a streamlined application process to remove unnecessary administrative barriers.

We therefore ask the House to ensure equitable access to the National Diabetes Services Scheme (NDSS) for individuals with cystic fibrosis-related diabetes (CFRD) throughout their lives. CFRD is a serious and complex condition that requires lifelong management, including continuous blood glucose monitoring, insulin therapy, and specialised nutritional support.

Currently, individuals with CFRD are only eligible for NDSS support until the age of 21, leaving adults with cystic fibrosis to face significant financial and logistical challenges in accessing essential diabetes care. This inequity places an undue burden on individuals and families, limiting their ability to maintain optimal health and quality of life. By ensuring ongoing access to the NDSS, the government can help prevent avoidable complications, reduce healthcare costs, and uphold the principle of health equity for all Australians living with cystic fibrosis.
from 1,892 citizens (Petition No. EN7148)
National Disability Insurance Scheme

Australia's disability support system is shifting responsibility from the NDIS to other government programs. While the intent is to ensure proper funding, participants are being removed before alternative supports are functional. This is not just a bureaucratic issue—it is a policy failure with real-world consequences.

People with disabilities should not be caught between state and federal funding disputes. What matters is ensuring they don't lose access to essential supports due to uncoordinated decisions. Services outside the NDIS remain underfunded and overstretched, with foundational supports still in development.

Mainstream services face wait times, workforce shortages, and funding gaps, and aren't yet ready to support additional participants. The government must ensure these systems are fully operational before moving people off the NDIS.

We therefore ask the House to call on the Australian government to immediately cease removing NDIS participants until the necessary systems and supports are fully in place. Specifically, we ask the government to:

Conduct a national audit of services to assess their capacity to meet the needs of people with disabilities, identifying gaps and developing a plan to address them before removing participants from the NDIS.
Implement a structured transition plan that ensures no one is left without support, including case management, clear referral pathways, and oversight mechanisms to monitor transitions.

Ensure reforms align with Australia's Disability Strategy, ensuring changes do not reduce access to essential supports and are co-designed with people with disabilities, their families, and representative organisations.
Until these protections and systems are in place, no participant should be removed.
from 153 citizens (Petition No. EN7149)
Asylum Seekers

This petition of citizens of Australia draws your attention to the thousands of Sri Lankan Tamil asylum seekers on Bridging Visas, who have been waiting in limbo for more than a decade for a decision through the "fast-track system" of the "legacy caseload". After seeking safety in Australia, many have assimilated into society and now contribute to our economy and multicultural nation in ways that mirror Australian citizens. Yet, they have the burden of a restrictive Bridging Visa barring them from becoming permanent residents in Australia through ordinary means.

These individuals pay income taxation, embody Australian values, fulfil skill shortages, keep small businesses alive and are ready to be recognised as Australians. It is not a "fair go" to wait this long for an outcome. It causes despair, and trauma and worsens mental health issues. There are grave concerns in the community due to the psychological damage and trauma this situation may cause in conjunction with the trauma caused by persecution and fleeing their home country. The recent death of Mr Mano Yogalingam, a man who spent eleven years on a bridging visa, is enough to highlight the gravity and urgency of this situation.

We therefore ask the House to through this petition, to act with humanity and kindness, and grant permanent residency to those in the "legacy caseload" who have waited far too long and deserve certainty of their future.
from 208 citizens (Petition No. EN7150)
Broadband

The National Broadband Network (NBN) was intended to provide Australians with fast, reliable, and affordable internet access. Unfortunately, many users experience slow speeds, frequent outages, and poor customer service. These issues affect both urban and regional areas, with regional Australians often left with substandard connectivity that limits their access to education, employment, and essential services. In an increasingly digital world, reliable internet is critical for individuals, businesses, and communities to thrive. The current state of the NBN is holding Australia back and causing frustration for countless citizens.
We therefore ask the House to
Conduct a comprehensive review of the NBN's infrastructure, addressing technical deficiencies and prioritizing upgrades to ensure consistent, high-speed internet for all Australians.
Provide additional funding to improve internet services in regional and remote areas, ensuring equitable access across the country.
Introduce measures to hold NBN service providers accountable for service quality, including penalties for failure to meet speed and reliability standards.
Explore opportunities for transitioning to more advanced technology, where feasible, to future-proof Australia's internet capabilities.
from 55 citizens (Petition No. EN7086)
Renewable Energy
Australian residents request the Federal Government to urgently halt the processing of renewable energy development applications.

These large-scale developments threaten irreversible harm to critical habitats for koalas, rock- wallabies, frogs, bats, birds, reptiles, greater gliders, raptors, insects and other threatened and endangered species. Heavy industrial equipment including bulldozers, explosives & haulage trucks, is required for these extensive energy complexes.

Extensive clearing for infrastructure including transmission lines, substations, concrete batching plants & battery storage systems are fragmenting Australia's critical habitats. Leaving irreversible impacts to the Great Dividing Range and catchments of the Great Barrier Reef.
We request decision-makers adhere to the precautionary principle, employing independent science and data in their assessments.

The EPBC laws should eliminate offsets, as they are deceptive and against the national interest. The 'renewable' energy industry lacks transparency, and independence. Governments are downplaying the significant environmental costs of fast-tracked development. This absence of accountability leaves communities feeling sidelined, as approvals are granted without adequate consultation.

It is projected that over 118 million hectares of land will be required to achieve net-zero targets. This includes vast areas of the Great Dividing Range, leading to industrial wastelands and an acceleration of wildlife extinctions. The fragmentation of critical habitats lacks social license.
Vast taxpayer-funded subsidies to multinational corporations is an unending transfer of wealth, undermining the national interest.
'Renewable' energy is not compatible with biodiversity, ecotourism, land care, and regional community values.
We therefore ask the House to immediate halt the processing of renewable energy development applications.
from 2,188 citizens (Petition No. EN7087)
Skilled Migration

We are raising urgent concerns about the prolonged delays in processing the 191 Permanent Residency Visa for 494/491 visa holders in Australia. Over the past 8 months, processing times have dramatically increased from 1 to 10 months, leaving thousands in limbo. Despite meeting all requirements, we are still waiting for a resolution, causing significant financial and emotional hardship.

In addition to these delays, many 494 visa holders are still bound by outdated TMSIT from 2021 or 2022, which limits career opportunities. The restrictions on remaining with the same employer and occupation add further pressure, making it difficult to progress professionally or financially.

Furthermore, it feels unfair that other visa subclasses are prioritised while 494/491 visa holders—who have supported Australia's economy, especially during the pandemic—continue to face significant delays in processing. This issue is not only causing uncertainty but also undermining our ability to fully contribute to the Australian workforce and build a stable future in the country.
We therefore ask the House to visa applications and expedite processing times by allocating more resources.
Provide flexibility for 494 visa holders to transition to new employers or occupations while waiting for their 191 visa, particularly given many are still under outdated TMSIT from 2021 or 2022.
Ensure equal treatment by prioritising 191 visa applications, especially for those who have contributed to the economy during the pandemic.
We respectfully request that the Australian Government take action to resolve these issues promptly.
from 6,285 citizens (Petition No. EN7088)
Middle East

We, the undersigned, bring to the attention of the House the ongoing violence, widespread persecution, and targeted atrocities in Syria, which constitute acts of genocide against certain communities. These actions have devastated the Syrian people and impacted many Australian families with loved ones trapped in dire conditions. International bodies, including human rights organizations, have documented war crimes, crimes against humanity, and systematic targeting of civilians, underscoring the urgent need for official recognition and action.

We therefore ask the House to declare these atrocities as genocide, call on the Federal Government to intensify diplomatic and humanitarian efforts, and implement expedited family reunification pathways to protect affected Australians and their loved ones. We further request a parliamentary debate on this crisis and support for measures ensuring accountability for perpetrators under international law.
from 4,174 citizens (Petition No. EN7090)
Climate Change

We should follow our alleys like the USA where Donald Trump signed an executive order to withdraw from the agreement. It will save the USA over 1 trillion dollars, so we can estimate that Australia will also save a similar amount. Its obligations disproportionately harm our industries, jobs, and energy costs, while allowing major emitters like China and India to increase their greenhouse gas emissions without similar constraints.
Our key concerns:

Compliance with the Paris Agreement threatens the vitality of Australia's key industries, including mining, agriculture, and manufacturing. The restrictions on emissions and energy usage risk substantial job losses and economic decline, especially in regions dependent on fossil fuel production.
The transition to renewable energy sources mandated by the agreement significantly increases electricity prices, placing undue strain on Australian households and businesses.

The agreement limits Australia's ability to set its own energy and environmental policies in response to our unique economic and environmental circumstances. We should have the freedom to prioritise our national interests without external interference.

While Australia is a minor contributor to global emissions, the agreement gives major polluters like China and India a free pass to expand their emissions. This creates an uneven playing field that unfairly disadvantages Australian businesses.
The measures required under the Paris Agreement are unlikely to achieve meaningful reductions in global temperatures, raising questions about its overall effectiveness and fairness.
We therefore ask the House to reconsider its commitment to the Paris Climate Agreement and adopt policies that place the interests of Australian Citizens first.
from 104 citizens (Petition No. EN7093)
Visa Refusal or Cancellation
we need to have a chris brown concert to cure all of australian citizens depression
We therefore ask the House to let chris brown come into australia
from seven citizens (Petition No. EN7094)
Antisemitism

Over the past few months Australia has witnessed the raise of antisemitic attacks. It began with the celebration in the very streets of Sydney suburbs on October 7th when Hamas attacked Israel and took many innocent civilians as hostages.

These acts are not an identity of this nation. Australia boasts in the anthem "We are one", however, this has been tainted with such awful acts of hatred. No religious places or suburbs were vandalised when Israel was attacked. But now, the Jewish community is being targeted in this nation, which is meant to be a safe haven for its citizens.

The latest attack on the daycare centre was absolutely devastating. Our kids are exposed to such antisocial behaviour. Targeting synagogues, centres or Jewish homes is not a an act of a brave heart but one that of cowardice.

Australia is a beautiful nation but it needs to be strong acting to curb these attacks. The government should act rather than holding to mere words of promises. Our Jewish friends need the assurance from the government and support from our communities during this time.
Take responsible action and stop antisemitism.
We therefore ask the House to consider taking immediate steps to stop attacks on Jewish communities in Australia.
from 79 citizens (Petition No. EN7095)
Taxation
Making all overtime tax free will boost the economy, and near eliminate cost of living crisis. More homes will be built and people will have hope again in this failing economy.
We therefore ask the House to remove all taxes from overtime to all jobs.
from 162 citizens (Petition No. EN7096)
Housing

With the exponential surge in housing prices across the country since the Covid-19 pandemic, home ownership has become increasingly elusive for many Australians, particularly the younger generation who have been unfairly disadvantaged due to their birth year. This growing housing affordability crisis, exacerbated by inadequate policy responses, threatens to undermine the social contract between Australia and its citizens. The repercussions of this trend could be far-reaching, including a decline in future birth rates, social cohesion, and ultimately the fabric of Australian society. To address this crisis, we urgently recommend that the House consider implementing measures such as capping residential ownership of investment properties, amending negative gearing rules, increasing the minimum lease agreement for rental properties, and penalising owners of vacant residential properties, among others. These proposed measures aim to promote a more equitable and sustainable housing market for all Australians.
We therefore ask the House to implement the following measures:
Cap investment property ownership at five standalone/townhouses and five apartments or a combined worth of $7.5 million.
Apply negative gearing rules only to new builds to encourage new housing investment.
Increase minimum lease agreement to 36 months for rental properties.
Penalise owners of vacant residential properties if Residential Vacancy Rates fall below 2.5%.

Implement a ban on short-term rentals where regional Residential Vacancy Rates fall below designated thresholds for each property type (e.g. 2.5% for 4- bedroom, 2% for 3-bedroom, and 1.5% for 2-bedroom).
These measures address the root causes of the housing affordability crisis and promote a more equitable and sustainable housing market for all Australians.
from 194 citizens (Petition No. EN7099)
Crime: Real Estate Industry

Money laundering through real estate poses a significant risk to the Australian economy and housing markets. Criminal organisations exploit weak regulations to launder illicit funds, inflating property prices and making housing less accessible for average citizens. Inadequate transparency in ownership structures and insufficient due diligence by industry professionals have created loopholes for these illegal activities to thrive.

This lack of regulation undermines public trust in the real estate market, perpetuates corruption, and facilitates the flow of dirty money into our communities. Moreover, it diverts legitimate investments away from industries that contribute to economic growth. Countries with robust anti-money laundering (AML) regulations in real estate have seen improved market stability and fairness.

By introducing stronger measures, we can protect housing affordability, ensure compliance with international AML standards, and prevent exploitation of the real estate sector by criminal enterprises. Failure to act now risks exacerbating these issues, further compromising housing accessibility and economic equity for future generations.
We therefore ask the House to the following actions to prevent money laundering in real estate:
Mandate disclosure of beneficial ownership for all property transactions.
Enforce enhanced due diligence on buyers, sellers, and cross-border transactions.
Ban cash payments over $10,000 and require reporting of such transactions.
Establish an independent body to audit and monitor real estate compliance.
Prohibit anonymous shell companies from holding property.
Implement mandatory AML training and certification for real estate professionals.
Impose substantial penalties for non- compliance, including license revocation.
By enacting these measures, we can safeguard the integrity of the real estate market and ensure it serves the public good.
from 86 citizens (Petition No. EN7100)
Economy

"We, the people, will no longer tolerate being treated as second-class citizens in our own land. Politicians and bureaucrats hoard wealth through extravagant pensions and privileges while ordinary Australians are left struggling. It is time to place YOU on the minimum wage, abolish your pensions until the standard retirement age, and hold you accountable for prioritising corporate interests over public welfare." Request:

We therefore ask the House to to fix Your exploitation of Australia's resources while offering minimal return to the people is unacceptable. We demand royalty schemes that give back to the Australian people—those who own this land. The era of unchecked profits at the expense of ordinary citizens is over."
from 51,351 citizens (Petition No. EN7101)
Climate Change

The Paris Agreement imposes significant economic burdens on Australia, particularly on industries critical to our economy, such as energy and mining. The commitments under the agreement risk increasing energy prices, limiting job opportunities, and affecting Australia's economic growth. Furthermore, Australia's emissions contribute minimally to global totals, yet the obligations disproportionately affect our country.

Exiting the agreement would allow Australia to implement its own environmental policies that better align with our national interests, while still addressing climate change through innovative and locally suited solutions.

We therefore ask the House to take the necessary legislative and diplomatic steps for Australia to withdraw from the Paris Agreement and regain full sovereignty over its energy and environmental policies.
from 344 citizens (Petition No. EN7104)
Pakistan: International Humanitarian Assistance

Parachinar Pakistan is under seige from the last 4 months from every sides . There is no Medicine for elders and kids and Almost 200 kids died because of non Availaiblity of life saving drugs.This is really a humaintarian issues facing by Citizens of Parachinar Pakistan.

Please come forward to send an emergency Aid ( medicine) through Red cross or by other means and make sure Pakistani Govt should take immeditae actions to open the roads and make it safe for Everyone living there. Thanks
We therefore ask the House to please come forward and take immediate actions to save kids of Parachinar Pakistan.
from 128 citizens (Petition No. EN7108)
Taxation: Cryptocurrency

Australia has some of the worst and convoluted tax laws regarding cryptocurrency. Not only is the tax rate one of the highest in the world (up to 45% when selling), there are also excessive taxes when utilising cryptocurrency in any form—i.e. swapping one crypto asset for another. This creates an immense backlog of paperwork as it is common for thousands of swaps to occur in a financial year. Inevitably, this means that it is near impossible to create an accurate tax filing for most crypto users.

Also, crypto sales are classified as capital gains. This means that to receive a tax break from an excessively high rate to a more modest rate, the user must hold the asset for 12 months or longer. While this may make sense in the property market, it is antithetical to the nature of cryptocurrency where holding an asset for too long may result in a net loss—and where swapping out of the asset or selling it under 12 months of acquiring it triggers a large taxable event under current laws.

Cryptocurrency is a growing industry in Australia which offers stability in a nation wrought with runaway inflation. Without laws to help foster in a fair and fertile ground for it, many young Aussies will migrate to countries with more common-sense tax rules.
We therefore ask the House to reform cryptocurrency taxes—simplify taxes by instituting a single 10-15% tax when converting crypto to fiat currency, with no additional taxes.
from 55 citizens (Petition No. EN7109)
Superannuation

Australian tax payers look forward to being eligible for their superannuation funds to become available, some of us , wish to retire early , and some wish to retire as late as possible , some of us have life plans , and would wish to withdraw a lump sum to complete a big purchase that may have been unachievable during working life, for example, a brand new car , or a property overseas etc..
We therefore ask the House to reconsider the restrictions imposed upon the taxpayer , resultant of the new superannuation laws recently passed
from 40 citizens (Petition No. EN7112)

subdebateinfo.title: Democratic Republic of Congo: International Humanitarian Assistance

p.span: Democratic Republic of Congo: International Humanitarian Assistance

The city of Goma in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) faces a severe humanitarian crisis due to ongoing conflict. The rebel group M23, reportedly supported by Rwanda, has launched attacks, displacing thousands of civilians who face food shortages, lack of medical care, and constant threats. This situation demands urgent international action.

As a nation committed to global peace and humanitarian causes, Australia has the capacity and moral obligation to assist. Our experience in providing aid and diplomatic support in conflict zones positions as to make a significant impact. The people of Goma urgently need food, medical supplies, and safe shelter. Diplomatic efforts are crucial to bring about a ceasefire and create conditions for lasting peace.
We therefore ask the House to Increase humanitarian aid to Goma, focusing on emergency food, medical supplies, and shelter for displaced persons.

Use diplomatic channels to advocate for an immediate ceasefire and peaceful resolution to the M23 conflict. Collaborate with international partners to support long- term peace-building efforts in the region.
Provide additional resources to Australian NGOs working in the DRC.
Raise awareness about the Goma crisis in international forums, highlighting the role of external support to M23, and encourage global support.
By acting now, Australia can alleviate immediate suffering, contribute to long-term regional stability, and demonstrate its commitment to global humanitarian leadership.
from 57 citizens (Petition No. EN7113)
Commonwealth Criminal Code

The term 'gender apartheid' is increasingly used to describe the institutionalised and systemic oppression of one gender group against other gender group/s, such as is currently the case in Iran and Afghanistan.

At the international level, Australia has been supporting the draft codification of gender apartheid under the Draft Articles on the Prevention and Punishment of Crimes Against Humanity at the Sixth Committee of the Unted Nations (UN). But that treaty is not due to be finalised until 2029.

Australia has a comprehensive legislative framework on crimes against humanity under Division 268 of the Commonwealth Criminal Code, which includes the crime of apartheid based on race. In line with Australia's international support for criminalisation of gender apartheid, there is an urgent need to amend the relevant division of the criminal code to include gender apartheid.

Such an amendment would be aligned with Australia's obligations under the Women, Peace and Security Agenda of the UN Security Council resolution 1325. As well as the principle of justice outlined in Australia's second National Action Plan on Women, Peace and Security.

Australia's criminalisation of gender apartheid under its national legislation will strengthen Australia's efforts at the international level and will be a crucial step towards recognition and criminalisation and under the forthcoming crimes against humanity treaty.

We therefore ask the House to incorporate gender apartheid into the current crime against humanity of apartheid in the Commonwealth Criminal Code, updating section 268.22 'Crime Against Humanity of Apartheid' of the Criminal Code Act (1995).
from 64 citizens (Petition No. EN7118)
First Nations Australians

As a First Nations individual, my experience with racism has been painful and far too common within our communities. From racial attacks to being denied employment due to bias, systemic racism impacts every aspect of our lives. First Nations people face unemployment rates nearly double the national average, a direct result of these inequities.

We ask policymakers at all levels of government to recognize and address these injustices. The dismantling of systemic racism requires meaningful action, starting with enforcing equal employment opportunity laws and holding those accountable who perpetuate discrimination.

Your support is crucial in pushing for these necessary changes. Together, we can create a fairer, more just society for all, particularly for First Nations communities. We urge you to sign this petition.

We therefore ask the House to This petition calls on the Australian government to act swiftly on issues impacting Aboriginal communities, particularly concerning Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. It urges the implementation of the 339 recommendations from the Royal Commission, focusing on mental health, addiction treatment, and justice reforms. Key recommendations include providing mental health and addiction care within justice institutions (Recommendation 150), restoring Medicare and PBS access, and creating culturally appropriate addiction treatment centres (Recommendation 287). The petition also supports the United Nations Mandela Rules, which advocate for education, employment, and housing for prisoners (Rules 104 and 105). Additionally, it calls for a duty of care in justice institutions (Recommendation 122) and addressing homelessness with Elder-supervised camping grounds and increased housing for Indigenous communities.
from 135 citizens (Petition No. EN7119)
Migration

As an Australian citizen and doctor, I humbly request your assistance in allowing our beloved mother to permanently reside with us under a Humanitarian Visa. Our mother resides in Brisbane with us and currently holds a 10-year medical visa. This visa for her health issues, was granted under Ministerial Intervention by Hon Peter Dutton in 2016. Our mother is unable to return to Kiribati as all her children and grandchildren live in Australia. Also, the absence of dialysis facilities, her return would result in her death within a matter of weeks.

We therefore ask the House to allow our loving mother to stay with her family indefinitely in Australia under Humanitarian Visa. She is a widow with three daughters, all of whom are Australian citizens/residents and actively contribute to society. I have dedicated my 20-year medical career to Australians, providing essential medical services. In the past three years, I worked only in Aboriginal Medical Services, where I actively work to bridge the gap for Australian Indigenous people. My two sisters both working in aged care are dedicated to assisting the aging population in Australia. We sincerely hope not to burden the Australian Government, and we diligently strive to ensure that our assimilation efforts are productive and meaningful. However, we do wish this elderly widow access to Medicare and the healthcare services she requires in Australia. Given her limited life expectancy, we kindly request that her children and grandchildren cherish the remaining time she has with them in Australia
from 1,636 citizens (Petition No. EN7121)
Parliamentary Standards

Members of Parliament are required to report on potential Conflicts of Interest. However, current COI standards are too narrow and do not carry harsh enough penalties for MPs who fail to adequately disclose such information, and should require them to publicly and visibly report on any meetings or non- monetary favors from People or Corporations of Interest (Industry leaders, CEOs, billionaires, lobbyist, etc).

Too many MPs have used misleading language, doublespeak and misrepresentation of motions presented to Parliament to pass bills that directly benefit industries and companies that then hire them after they leave their government position.
The people of Australia have a right to honesty, integrity and transparency from their representatives.
We therefore ask the House to :

Enforce public and visible reports on meetings and non-monetary gifts/favors (Eg. Dinner invitations, reservations to exclusive venues, prioritization of Members of Parliament and family/friends on waiting lists, etc)

Impose harsher penalties on Members of Parliament who fail to adequately disclose potential Conflicts of Interest, including but not limited to fines and potential disbarment from current and future government positions.
Require Members of Parliament to disclose relevant lobbyists or Persons of Interest they have discussed potential legislation with who stand to benefit from the presented bill and/or motion.
To impose penalties for use of misleading language or outright misrepresentation of proposed motions and/or motions and supporting evidence and data.
from 175 citizens (Petition No. EN7122)
Petitions received.
PETITIONS
Responses
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (09:16): by leave—I present the following 30 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
Climate Change
Dear Chair

Thank you for your referral of 20 June 2023 of a petition for creating a federal community of scientists to research climate change (EN5101). I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

The Albanese Labor Government accepts the scientific facts of climate change. The Government receives its primary advice on climate science from the Bureau of Meteorology and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO). The scientific advice from these agencies aligns with information provided by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) and other trusted national and international organisations, such as the Australian Academy of Science, the World Meteorological Organization, the National Academy of Sciences, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

These world-leading scientific organisations have found that the Earth's climate is changing and that humans are primarily responsible, due to emissions of greenhouse gases from the combustion of fossil fuels and land use change. These findings are informed by long-term, real-world scientific observations of air temperatures, atmospheric greenhouse gas concentrations, the heat content of the ocean, changes to vegetation, glaciers, ice sheets and sea ice and many other climate variables.

The IPCC is a trusted source of scientific advice, and its work continues to inform the Government. The recent IPCC sixth Assessment Report provides an update on the latest t climate science, and options for mitigating and adapting to climate change. In this report, the IPCC notes that deep, rapid and sustained reductions in greenhouse gas emissions are required to meet the Paris Agreement goals of keeping global warming to well below 2°C above pre- industrial levels and pursuing efforts to limit global warming to 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels. They further note that this would lead to a discernible slowdown in global warming within around two decades, and also to discernible changes in atmospheric composition within a few years.
The world's leading scientists agree emissions must reach net zero by 2050. We are working with countries around the world to achieve this.
Thank you for bringing the petitioners' concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, Mr Bowen
Renewable Energy
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 12 February 2024 regarding petition EN5680, which asks to commit to a moratorium on all large-scale wind, solar, pumped hydro and related transmission projects. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention, and I apologise for the delay in responding.

The development of new renewable energy generation projects is essential to the stability and sustainability of Australia's energy system as aging coal-fired power stations reach end of life and are retired. The rollout of renewable energy such as solar and wind are the cheapest and most efficient pathway to replacing the aging power stations that can no longer meet Australia's long-term needs. This transition to renewable generation will contribute to achieving net zero carbon emissions by 2050, and is part of a global transition to ensure the decarbonisation of energy systems.
The Australian Government expects renewable energy infrastructure essential to the clean energy transition to be well-planned, built in suitable areas, and to benefit affected communities.

Accordingly, the Australian Energy Infrastructure Commissioner's (AEIC) primary role is to identify and promote best practice relating to the planning, development and operation of renewable energy projects and new transmission, facilitate the referral and resolution of complaints from concerned residents, and provide greater transparency on information and knowledge relating to renewable energy infrastructure and major new transmission.

New renewable energy projects are also required to conduct extensive environmental assessments and may need approval under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act). Experts within the Nature Positive Regulation Division of the Department of Climate Change, Energy, the Environment and Water review these assessments. Where the Department and the Minister for the Environment and Water are not satisfied the studies submitted are adequate or do not demonstrate a project will be able to avoid or mitigate environmental impacts to an acceptable level, approval under the EPBC Act will not be provided and a project will be unable to proceed.

The Department believes effective community engagement is paramount to meeting government requirements and community expectations. Community engagement mitigates potential risks to affected communities and ensures the benefits of the energy transition, including affordable energy, are distributed equitably.

In 2023, I successfully sought a change the National Energy Rules (NER) to enhance the community engagement practises of Transmission Network Service Providers. The new rule change was approved on 9 November 2023. In recognition of the unique challenges created by transmission lines, the department also developed the 'National Guidelines for Community Engagement and Benefits for Electricity Transmission Projects' to encourage better practice in community engagement, impact management and benefit sharing for new transmission infrastructure. These guidelines were published on 19 July 2024.

To advise on how to improve community engagement by developers, I commissioned the AEIC to conduct the Community Engagement Review (the Review), which was publicly released on the 2 February 2024. The Government has accepted all nine recommendations in principle. The. Review report and the Government response are available at
www.dcceew.gov.au/energy/renewable/community-engagement-review.

The Government is working through the Energy and Climate Change Ministerial Council (ECMC) to progress the Review recommendations. The ECMC response to the Review considers and highlights the broad range of initiatives already being progressed by the Commonwealth, states and territories, and through the National Energy Transformation Partnership, and how these can be built on to further enhance community outcomes and engagement on renewable energy and transmission infrastructure projects. The ECMC response and Schedule of Activities can be found here: www.energy.gov.au/energy-and-climate-change-ministerial-council.
The Review identified key areas for improvement, many of which are relevant to the concerns noted in petition EN5680, such as:
Establishing a national developer ratings scheme to incentivise better engagement by developers
Encouraging best practice and selecting reputable developers for new projects
Reducing unnecessary and onerous community engagement by improving the way project sites are selected
Making engagement more efficient by revising planning and approval processes
Improving complaint handling processes
Keeping communities informed about the transition—its goals, benefits and requirements
Sharing the benefits of the transition equitably.
In the most recent budget, the department received funding for several measures stemming from the Review:

The AEIC will transition to a non-statutory Ministerial appointment and hire additional staff, enhancing its independence and ability to address anti-renewables misinformation, support First Nations peoples and improve complaint resolutions.

A developer rating scheme will be developed to encourage best practices and foster transparency and trust between developers and communities, with input from a diverse range of stakeholders, including funded assistance from the Clean Energy Regulator (CER).
The Department is exploring options for delivering bill relief and distributing additional benefits equitably in regions most affected by renewable energy developments.
Further information on the renewable energy transformation is available at www.dcceew.gov.au/energy/supply.
Thank you again for bringing the petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, Mr Bowen
Human Rights: Occupied Palestinian Territories
Dear Chair
Thank you for referring petition EN6472 regarding Israel's actions in the Occupied Palestinian Territories.
I know the conflict in the Middle East is deeply distressing for many Australians, including the many Australians with a connection to the region and loved ones directly impacted.

Australia respects the independence of the International Court of Justice (ICJ) and the critical role it plays in upholding international law and the rules-based order. The Prime Minister has publicly called on Israel to respond substantively to the ICJ's advisory opinion of 19 July and ensure accountability for ongoing acts of violence against Palestinians by extremist settlers, reverse the record of expansion of settlements in the West Bank, and work towards a two-state solution.

The Albanese Government has been firm and consistent that Israeli settlements are illegal under international law and a significant obstacle to peace. I reiterated this position in a statement on 25 July 2024 and in the Senate on 4 July 2024, where I also expressed Australia's opposition to the Netanyahu Government's approval of new settlement construction in the West Bank. We continue to press Israel, publicly and privately, to cease its settlement activity.

We condemn the ongoing settler violence in the West Bank and are taking action against perpetrators. On 25 July 2024, the Australian Government imposed Magnitsky-style targeted sanctions on seven Israeli individuals and one entity for their involvement in the abhorrent settler violence terrorising Palestinian communities. The Australian Government will also deny anyone identified as an extremist settler a visa to travel to Australia. I reiterate Australia's call on Israel to do more to protect the Palestinian civilian population.
Australia remains steadfast in our support for a two-state solution—a Palestinian state and the State of Israel, living side by side in peace and security within internationally recognised borders.
I trust this information will be of assistance to the petitioners.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Corporate Governance
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence originally directed to the Treasurer, the Hon Dr. Jim Chalmers MP, concerning Petition EN6483 on Incy Interiors Pty Ltd's (lncy Interiors) and requesting the House to bring Incy Interiors' conduct to the attention of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC), the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) and other relevant government agencies. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.
I note the petitioners' concerns around Incy Interiors' failure to fulfil its consumer obligations under the Australian Consumer Law (ACL).

The ACL prohibits businesses from engaging in conduct that is unconscionable, misleading, or deceptive, and from accepting payment if they do not intend to supply the product or service. The ACL also provides consumers with statutory rights called consumer guarantees, which are intended to ensure consumers get what they paid for. Where a consumer guarantee has not been met, consumers are entitled to request a remedy from the business which may include repair, replacement or refund. The ACCC and consumer protection agencies in each state and territory enforce compliance with the ACL.

I understand that Incy Interiors entered liquidation on 30 January 2024. When a business enters liquidation, consumers' ordinary legal rights can be affected. This restricts the ability of regulators to take action under the ACL. Further information on how insolvency affects consumers' legal rights can be accessed at www.accc.gov.au/consumers/stay-protected/when-a-business-goes-bust.

The ACCC is aware of issues regarding Incy Interiors. The ACCC understands that Incy Interiors sold assets to another company, Impressive Imports Pty Ltd (Impressive Imports), which is continuing to trade using the "Incy Interiors" business name, website and contact details. The ACCC understands that the report of the liquidator for Incy Interiors noted that the sale contract to Impressive Imports required it to fulfil outstanding orders consumers had made with Incy Interiors.

If consumers who had made orders with Incy Interiors pre-liquidation continue to have issues receiving their outstanding orders, and cannot resolve these with the business directly, they should contact the appointed liquidator of lncy Interiors, Mr Darrin Paine of TI Group (NSW) Pty Ltd, on 1300 844 679 or at dpaine@tigroup.net.au.

If consumers have made orders with Incy Interiors post-liquidation and have issues, they should try to resolve the issue directly with the business. If they are not able to do so, they can report the issue to their local state or territory consumer protection agency, which may be able to assist them.

The ACCC is also aware that NSW Office of Fair Trading has engaged with Impressive Imports about outstanding orders. Consumers who have paid for their order with a credit card, debit card or through a secure payment provider such as PayPal may wish to submit a chargeback claim to their payment provider as soon as possible (noting there are time limits on raising a chargeback).

I further note the petitioners' concerns on Incy Interiors' involvement in potential illegal phoenix activity. Illegal phoenix activity is when a new company is created to continue the business of an existing company that has been liquidated to avoid liabilities, including trade debts, taxes and employee entitlements.

I can assure you that allegations of this magnitude are treated with the utmost concern. Treasury has forwarded your letter to the Australian Taxation Office's (ATO) Phoenix Taskforce. The intelligence gathered will be shared as appropriate with members of the Phoenix Taskforce, which is a cross-government taskforce dedicated to stamping out illegal phoenix activity and prosecuting offenders.

I would also encourage impacted individuals to also report any potential illegal phoenix activity via the ATO on 1800 060 062 or through an online form available at www.ato.gov.au/forms-and-instructions/tax-evasion-reporting-form.

In addition, liquidators have an obligation to investigate the financial affairs of the company and lodge reports with ASIC about possible offences and misconduct by officers and directors of the company (including potential involvement in illegal phoenix activity). Liquidators also have a range of mechanisms to address incidents of phoenix activity, including making an application to reverse unreasonable payments to directors, uncommercial transactions and creditor defeating dispositions.
Impacted individuals may also wish to report any instances of misconduct by company directors/officers and registered liquidators directly to ASIC at:
www.asic.gov.au/about-asic/contact-us/reporting-misconduct-to-asic/make-a-report-of-misconduct-to-asic/.

In determining which matters to pursue, either for further investigation or prosecution, ASIC considers a broad range of factors. These considerations include the likelihood that the alleged misconduct may have occurred, the nature and seriousness of the allegations and whether a prosecution is likely to be successful.

ASIC is an independent statutory authority established under the Australian Securities and Investments Commission Act 2001 (the ASIC Act) and is responsible for the administration and enforcement of the Corporations Act 2001. Under the ASIC Act, the Minister is specifically precluded from giving ASIC a direction about its policies or priorities in relation to a particular case.
