This is to ensure that ASIC's decisions and actions are independent of the political process. As such, I am unable to direct ASIC or otherwise intervene in the circumstances raised in this petition.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer and Minister for Financial Services, Mr Jones

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Veterans' Affairs: Allied Health Rebates

p.span: Department of Veterans' Affairs: Allied Health Rebates
Dear Ms Templeman
PETITION NUMBER: EN6526

Thank you for your referral of petition number EN6526—'Treating DVA patients is sending Australian physiotherapy private practices broke' of 8 October 2024, which requests that the House consider legislating an increase in fees paid to private physiotherapy clinics treating Veteran Card Holders. I apologise for the delay in responding. The Australian Government recognises the expertise and continued dedication of physiotherapists in delivering high-quality services to the veteran community.

The Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA) monitors access to health services and how this might be impacted by a range of factors, including the level of fees paid to providers. In 2023-24 there were over 13,300 physiotherapists who accepted the Veteran Card as full payment for their services, which is an increase of 5 per cent from 2022-23.

In the 2023-24 Budget, the Albanese Labor Government made changes to indexation arrangements for various programs, including DVA health care arrangements, which represented the largest increase to indexation in 30 years. This meant fees for DVA health services were indexed by 3.6 per cent in July 2023, with an additional adjustment of 0.5 per cent on 1 November 2023. This new methodology continues to be applied to indexation of DVA provider fees each year, including on 1 July 2024 when provider fees were again indexed by 3.5 per cent.

As you would be aware, the Royal Commission into Defence and Veteran Suicide Final Report recommended increasing the DVA fee schedule so it is aligned with that of the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS) (recommendation 71).

On 2 December 2024, the Albanese Labor Government released its Response to the Final Report of the Royal Commission. The Government noted recommendation 71 for further consideration by the Taskforce being established in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet to consider detailed implementation for those recommendations which were agreed in-principle or noted. The Government response to the Royal Commission is available via the DVA website at www.dva.gov.au/documents-and-publications/governments-response- royal-commissions-final-report.
Thank you for taking the time to bring this matter to my attention. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours faithfully
from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister for Defence Personnel, Mr Keogh
Domestic and Family Violence
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 3 November 2024 enclosing Petition EN6552 regarding domestic violence (DV), and requesting the House implement accountability measures to hold individuals who knowingly make false DV accusations accountable.

The Australian Government is firm in its view that family violence is unacceptable, and is committed to an Australia that is free from violence against women and children, where women are safe and respected at home, in the workplace and online.

It is not the role of the family courts to determine the criminal guilt or innocence of a party with respect to allegations of family violence, criminal offences and the criminal justice system more broadly. Such matters are heard by the State and Territory criminal courts and are appropriately a matter for the police, child welfare and prosecuting authorities.

The issue of managing false allegations of DV within family law proceedings remains a role for the courts and specifically, for family law court judges, to consider the evidence presented, including allegations of family violence, and determine the weight it should be given.

If a party is dissatisfied with a decision of the court, the only way to challenge that decision is through the appeal procedures set out in the Family Law Act 1975 (the Family Law Act). An appeal enables a person involved in legal proceedings to challenge a decision of a court. The appeal process is a fundamental part of our legal system in that it affords people the right to challenge decisions which affect their legal rights. Further information on the appeal process can be obtained from:
www.fcfcoa.gov.au/fl/appeals.

The Family Law Courts have broad powers to order costs against a party if false allegations or false denials are proven in court. In addition, a witness in proceedings who wilfully makes a statement significant to the proceedings which they know to be false, or do not believe to be true, may have committed the offence of perjury.

Where there is an allegation of perjury, the court may refer the allegation to the Australian Federal Police (AFP) for investigation. The AFP is operationally independent of Government and has authority to make decisions about whether or not to investigate an alleged Commonwealth offence.

The Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia has broad powers to manage the conduct of proceedings and can make orders to prevent misuse of court processes, including the power to summarily dismiss all or any part of proceedings that it considers frivolous, vexatious or an abuse of process.
You and the Petitioner may be interested to know that the Attorney-General's Department (the department) is currently leading a number of measures such as:

Enhancing law enforcement responses to family, domestic and sexual violence (FDSV) through the development and delivery of a national training package for the use of Commonwealth, state and territory police. This is funded under the National Plan to End Violence Against Women & Children 2022—2032 (National Plan).

Working with the States and Territories through the Family Violence Working Group of the Standing Council of Attorneys-General, the Australian Government is developing options for improving the family safety competency of legal practitioners, including opportunities for professional development for those working in the family law and family violence systems.

Co-funding measures with the States and Territories to improve the family safety competency of judicial officers, such as the delivery of the Family Violence in the Court training program, and the development and maintenance of a National Domestic and Family Violence Bench Book. The Bench Book contains a section on unmeritorious, harmful or vexatious proceedings, which recognise the abuse of process to cause detriment or other wrongful purpose used by perpetrators in the course of legal proceedings.
Thank you again for bringing the Petitioners' request to the Government's attention. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus KC
Charitable Organisations: Coercive Control
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 3 November 2024 regarding Petition EN6576 (the Petition) about the criminalisation of coercive control by an organisation, particularly within cult-like organisations.

The Australian Government recognises the seriousness of coercive control and the detrimental impact it can have on individuals. The Australian Government and State and Territory governments recently developed the National Principles to Address Coercive Control in Family and Domestic Violence (National Principles), which outline a shared understanding of coercive control and its impacts (available at www.ag.gov.au/coercivecontrol). The National Principles acknowledge that coercive control can be perpetrated in the broad context of gender-based violence and other circumstances where there are unequal power relationships.

I understand the Petition specifically requests the criminalisation of coercive control by organisations. Whether coercive control should be a specific criminal offence, and the form this may take, is a matter for individual state and territory governments.

I also note the Petition's concerns about the Shincheonji Church. While I note these concerns, section 116 of the Australian Constitution prevents the Commonwealth from passing laws establishing any religion, imposing any religious observance or prohibiting the free exercise of religion. All Australians are free to choose their religion, and are entitled to express and practice their religion and their beliefs, without intimidation and without interference, as long as those practices are within the framework of Australian law.

Should an individual believe the actions of the Shincheonji Church, or any other individual or organisation, breach any criminal laws, evidence should be provided to local state or territory police. Police operate independently of government and the decision whether or not to investigate an alleged offence is a matter for their determination.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus KC
Defence Procurement
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 4 November 2024 presenting Petition EN6580—Cancel the AUKUS Agreement. I have given careful consideration to the matters raised in the petition.

The Albanese Government recognises that the first responsibility of a government is to provide for the safety and security of its people. The AUKUS partnership is a core pillar of the Albanese Government's national security policy to protect our nation, its interests and security. We confront the most challenging strategic circumstances since the Second World War, and we do so at a time when Australia's economic connection with the world has never been greater.

These observations are at the core of our 2024 National Defence Strategy, which the Government delivered in April last year. It reaffirmed that our strategic environment has continued to deteriorate, consistent with the trends identified in the 2023 Defence Strategic Review. To meet the strategic challenges Australia faces, the Government is investing in a generational uplift in Defence's capabilities to deter any potential adversary from succeeding in coercing Australia through force; to support regional security and prosperity; and to help uphold a favourable regional strategic balance.

The Albanese Government also recognises that we must contribute to the collective security of the Inda-Pacific because our security and prosperity depend on the stability and security of our region. Yet we need to contend with the reality that our region is witnessing the largest conventional military build-up the world has seen in decades. We do not question the right of countries to invest in and develop defence capabilities, but this must be done transparently and with strategic reassurance. We need to ensure the Inda-Pacific remains a region where all countries—big or small—are able to act in their sovereign interests to shape their own future free from coercion.

The acquisition of conventionally-armed, nuclear-powered submarines will enable Australia to better contribute to a sovereign and resilient Inda-Pacific and to deter aggression more effectively. These submarines will be owned, operated, maintained and regulated by Australia and under Australian command. For a maritime trading nation like Australia, maintaining a submarine capability advantage over potential adversaries is vital. Closing or blocking sea lanes would have a devastating impact on Australia's economy and security, and on partners in South East Asia, the Pacific, and globally. By investing in these high-end capabilities, Australia is contributing to a more stable, secure and prosperous region, and is better placed to protect our national interests.

We recognise the investment in Australia's conventionally-armed nuclear-powered submarine program is significant. This will be one of the greatest industrial endeavours Australia has ever undertaken, supporting industry, jobs and infrastructure. We plan to invest over $30 billion in Australian industry alone as part of this program, which will support over 20,000 jobs over the next three decades.
Thank you again for forwarding Petition EN6580 for my consideration.
Yours sincerely
from the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence, Mr Marles
Youth Justice
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 03 November 2024 regarding petition number EN6598 urging the Australian Government to reform federal legislation on 'child-on-child sexual abuse', which is also referred to as harmful sexual behaviours displayed by children and young people.
I note this petition primarily focuses on improving protections and support for victims of child on child sexual abuse and to ensure that offenders are held accountable for their behaviour.

I want to reassure you that child safety is a key priority for the Australian Government. Every child and young person has the right to be safe from child sexual abuse. It is our collective responsibility to protect them and ensure that strong frameworks are in place to create safe environments for children and young people in all settings.

The Australian Government is leading a significant program of work to protect Australian children from child sexual abuse and related harms including under the National Strategy to Prevent and Respond to Child Sexual Abuse 2021-2030 (National Strategy)—https://www.childsafety.gov.au/resources/national-strategy-prevent-and-respond-child-sexual-abuse-2021-2030. The National Strategy is a nationally coordinated, strategic framework for preventing and responding to child sexual abuse. The National Office for Child Safety (National Office) within my department is responsible for overseeing the implementation of the National Strategy.

span.span: Federal laws concerning the minimum age of criminal responsibility for sexual offences:

p.span: I note your petition requests a review and amendment of the federal laws concerning the minimum age of criminal responsibility for sexual offences. As noted in your petition, currently, the principle of doli incapax applies in all jurisdictions for children aged at or above the minimum age of criminal responsibility but below 14 years. The principle of doli incapax means these children cannot be held criminally responsible for an offence, unless it is proven that they knew (or had the capacity to know) what they were doing was seriously wrong at the time of the alleged offending.

The Commonwealth Criminal Code contains a robust child sexual abuse offence framework, and is complemented by offences across state and territory jurisdictions. For the most part, state and territory governments have responsibility for justice responses to criminal offences relating to harmful sexual behaviours. Responses will vary depending on legislation within each jurisdiction.

For Commonwealth offences, my consent is required before commencing proceedings in relation to certain offences, where a defendant was under 18 years of age at the time of the alleged offending (for example, offences contained in Division 272—Child Sex Offences outside Australia, and Subdivision D—Offences relating to use of carriage service for child abuse material). Other offences (such as those in Division F—Offences relating to the use of carriage service involving sexual activity with, or causing harm to, person under 16) require the alleged offender to be at least 18 years of age at the time of the offence.

Under the National Strategy, my department is reviewing existing Commonwealth child sexual abuse offences. This review is expected to progress in 2025 and may look at legislative reforms to make sure offences remain current and reflect emerging trends. Further information about this review can be found in the National Strategy Second Annual Report 2024.

The National Strategy has a strong focus on improving prevention and responses to children and young people who have displayed harmful sexual behaviours. Responding to harmful sexual behaviours should prioritise the safety of all children and young people, their families, carers, kin and the wider community. It is acknowledged that some behaviours will require a criminal justice response. However, alongside any criminal justice response, I note that a therapeutic response can contribute significantly to preventing these behaviours reoccurring or escalating. The work under the National Strategy aims to ensure children and young people will have timely access to evidence-based therapeutic support at the onset of concerning or harmful sexual behaviours, to help prevent these behaviours from escalating or reoccurring.

span.span: Psychological and emotional supports for victims and survivors of child sexual abuse:

p.span: I note your petition raised the importance of providing psychological and emotional support services to victims and survivors during the criminal justice process. Part IAD of the Crimes Act 1914 (Cth) (the Crimes Act) sets out protections for vulnerable persons in Commonwealth criminal proceedings. The Crimes Amendment (Strengthening the Criminal Justice Response to Sexual Violence) Act 2024 (Cth) (the Act) amends the Crimes Act to strengthen these protections and received royal assent on 10 December 2024. The Act implements trauma-informed measures that better support vulnerable persons when appearing as complainants and/or witnesses in Commonwealth criminal proceedings. Under the Crimes Act, vulnerable persons include a victim or witness who is under the age of 18.

There are also a number of Australian Government-funded legal support services for children and young people. For example, Youth Law Australia (YLA) has been funded to operate an online chat service to deliver free legal assistance to children and young people experiencing or at risk of harm. This is part of the Enhance and Expand Legal Assistance Services for Victims and Survivors of Child Sexual Abuse program under the National Strategy. YLA's online chat service includes information about other available options for assistance outside of business hours, and identifies that support from a social worker or counsellor is available through the online chat service where required.

Under the National Strategy, knowmore Legal Service has also been funded to expand its national specialist trauma-informed legal service outside the institutional context. Clients engaging with knowmore are offered counselling and social work services as well as cultural support and referrals if required. More broadly, knowmore is funded to provide legal support services for survivors engaging with the National Redress Scheme for people who have experienced institutional child sexual abuse.

It is critically important that victims and survivors of child sexual abuse can access support when they need it, noting that they may seek help from a range of support services at different points in their lives. There are psychological and emotional support services available throughout the country, the vast majority of which are low cost or free. These services provide a wide range of support including therapeutic support, legal advice, advocacy or other support services. Individuals can find a list of national services on childsafety.gov.au or find locally-run services by searching in their relevant jurisdiction.

Under the National Strategy, the Australian Government is establishing a national information and referral service to assist victims and survivors of child sexual abuse, practitioners and the general public to navigate the service system and to access help and information. The service will include a national website, national helpline and specialist child sexual abuse service navigators, and offer a central point of access to information, resources and referrals to targeted and broad support services. The National Office anticipates the new national information and referral service will commence by the end of 2025.

I want to reiterate that the Australian Government is committed to protecting children from sexual abuse. As part of this, the National Office is working to ensure that children and young people who have displayed harmful sexual behaviours understand the consequences and impacts of their behaviour, while also being provided therapeutic support to stop behaviours from recurring or escalating.

Please be assured that child safety is a key priority of the Australian Government. We know there is more work to do to protect children and young people from sexual abuse and related harms in Australia, and to better support victims and survivors. Child sexual abuse is preventable and it requires collective effort to ensure children and young people in Australia are safe from harm.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus KC
Goldmining: Dittmer Project
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence in relation to Petition EN6605, concerning investigations being undertaken by Ballymore Resources Pty Ltd (Ballymore) into reopening the inactive underground Dittmer Gold Mine in Dittmer, Queensland. The petition raises concerns held by members of the public over various potential impacts of reopening the mine.

I note that some of the concerns raised in Petition EN6605 relate to matters of national environmental significance protected under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act). These include the endangered Proserpine Rock Wallaby and the Great Barrier Reef (Marine Park, World Heritage Property and National Heritage Place). Some other matters, such as the protection of local waterways and the allocation of water resources, are the responsibility of the Queensland Government.

The Department of Climate Change, Energy, the Environment and Water has met with Ballymore to inform them of their obligations under the EPBC Act. The Department has advised they are confident that Ballymore understands these obligations. At this stage, neither I nor the Department have given Ballymore any directions, approvals or assurances in relation to the Dittmer Gold Mine.
I and the Department have noted the contents of Petition EN6605 for reference in any future dealings with Ballymore in relation to the Dittmer Gold Mine.
Thank you again for your correspondence.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment and Water, Ms Plibersek
International Relations: Australia and Nicaragua
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email on behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions concerning petition EN6648.

The Australian Government is gravely concerned by the deteriorating human rights situation in Nicaragua, including the suppression of academic freedom and reprisals against civil society organisations, Indigenous leaders and the media. We have publicly called on the Nicaragua Government to adhere to its human rights obligations, including at the United Nations.

For example, on 13 September 2022, Australia led a statement on behalf of 46 countries at the 51st Session of the UN Human Rights Council calling on Nicaragua to, inter alia, end suppression of universities and the media.

Australia has made statements during interactive dialogues at the UN with the High Commissioner on Nicaragua (16 June 2022) and the Group of Human Rights Experts on Nicaragua (6 March 2023), where we called for an end to repression of political opponents, human rights defenders, journalists and the clergy.

Australia is a traditional co-sponsor of the Human Rights Council resolution on the promotion and protection of human rights in Nicaragua (most recently at HRC52, April 2023). This resolution expressed profound concern at the repression of civil society organisations, universities and independent media outlets and called on Nicaragua to restore the independence and academic freedom of universities.

On 1 November 2024, Australia joined a statement at the 352nd Session of the International Labour Organization Governing Body condemning human rights violations and abuses across Nicaragua through the non-observance by Nicaragua of Conventions No 87 (Freedom of Association and Protection of the Right to Organise), 98 (Right to Organise and Collective Bargain), 111 (Discrimination in Respect of Employment and Occupation) and 144 (International Labour Standards).

Most recently, at the Human Rights Council's Universal Periodic Review of Nicaragua on 13 November 2024, Australia made a statement calling on Nicaragua to restore the citizenship and assets of people stripped of their citizenship and provide guarantees for their safe return without reprisal; reinstate legal status to civil society organisations, religious and other associations as a matter of urgency; and conduct free and transparent elections in 2026.
The Government will continue to call on the Nicaragua Government to return to democracy and fully respect human rights and academic freedom.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Road Safety: CB Radio Operation
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 18 November 2024 regarding Petition EN6662—request to influence states and territories to mandate hands-free citizen band (CB) radio operation with 895 signatures. I apologise for the delay in responding.

I am deeply saddened by the death of Katrina Roberts and the impact this has had on her family. As the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, I have a deep sense of responsibility towards my role, which includes road safety, as it has a real impact on the lives of all Australians, from the cities to the country.

Under Australia's federal system of government, states and territories are responsible for the governing and enforcement of their own road traffic regulations, which includes the use of CB radios whilst driving within each jurisdiction.

Therefore, I have requested my colleague, Senator the Hon Anthony Chisholm, who is responsible for the road safety activities and initiatives within my portfolio, to write to his road safety state and territory ministerial counterparts, suggesting that they review CB radio regulations in their jurisdictions and consider mandating the use of hands-free CB radio.
Thank you for taking the time to write to me on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, Ms C King
Middle East
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your letter regarding EN6683 on the protection of Jewish people.

The Australian Government is unequivocal in its condemnation of Hamas' abhorrent attacks on 7 October 2023 and ongoing acts of terror. The Australian Government lists Hamas as a terrorist organisation in its entirety under the Criminal Code Act 1995. Since October 2023, Australia has coordinated with partners to apply additional sanctions against Hamas, as well as Hizballah and others for their terrorism.

The Australian Government has repeatedly called for the immediate and unconditional release of hostages. I have pressed countries with influence over Hamas to help secure their release. Australia sees no role for Hamas in the future governance of Gaza. A future Palestinian state cannot be in a position to threaten Israel's security.

Australia supports the ceasefire and hostage agreement in Gaza and urges all parties to respect the terms of the agreement and for all phases of the deal to be implement in full, including to secure the release of the remaining hostages.

Australia affirms Israel's right to defend itself in accordance with international law. International law includes the United Nations Charter that allows countries to defend themselves—and the Geneva Conventions that protect civilians during wars.

We condemn antisemitism in Australia. Every Australian, no matter their race or religion should be able to enjoy their life in any Australian community, without prejudice or discrimination. We understand incidents of antisemitism can leave communities feeling targeted, threatened, and vulnerable.

Since October 2023, the Australian Government has awarded $78.6 million to Jewish organisations nationally to enhance security at Jewish community sites, including places of worship, schools, pre-schools and Jewish community centres.

We will not tolerate crimes that undermine Australia's security or our inclusive way of life. The Australian Federal Police will lead Special Operation Avalite to investigate threats, violence and hatred towards the Australian Jewish community and parliamentarians.

The Government is also seeking to strengthen, and build upon, legislative protections against hatred and extremism with the Criminal Code Amendment (Hate Crimes) Bill, which was introduced to the Parliament in September 2024. The Bill would address significant increases in antisemitism and lslamophobia in Australia by criminalising the most serious kinds of hate speech involving force or violence. This builds on reforms last year that created criminal offences for publicly displaying and trading in Nazi and terrorist organisation symbols, performing the Nazi salute in a public place, and dealing with violent extremist material.

As part of the Australian Government's ongoing efforts to improve social cohesion in Australia, including fostering inter-faith dialogue, the Government has appointed a Special Envoy to Combat Antisemitism, Ms Jillian Segal AO, and a Special Envoy to Combat lslamophobia, Mr Aftab Malik. The Special Envoys are listening and engaging with stakeholders, including communities, academics and other experts, to better understand, identify and address the drivers of Antisemitic and lslamophobic behaviour. The Government has also appointed Peter Khalil MP as the Special Envoy for Social Cohesion.
Inclusion, respect and other shared values that keep our communities strong and cohesive are more important than ever during difficult periods such as these.

We will continue to work across the community to foster greater social cohesion, greater understanding and inclusion of all communities that contribute to our vibrant and resilient multicultural society.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Melbourne Airport
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 18 November 2024 enclosing Petition EN6689, with 226 signatures, concerning my decision to approve the development of a third runway at Melbourne Airport (M3R).
My decision to approve the M3R Major Development Plan (MDP) was not taken lightly. Throughout my consideration of the M3R MDP, the needs of the local community were front of mind.

I draw your attention to the comprehensive set of conditions I imposed for the construction and operation of the new runway. These represent the most comprehensive set of conditions for a project of this type, including:
Melbourne Airport providing a legally-enforceable commitment to restore the length of the existing east-west runway to maximise the opportunities for noise sharing;
Design and implementation of a noise sharing and airspace plan that prioritises sharing of aircraft noise between affected areas;
Implementation of a noise amelioration program in the communities most impacted; and

Conducting a Community Health Study into the impacts of noise before and after the establishment of the third runway, recording baseline data in the lead up to and for the first 20 years of the operation of the third runway.

The conditions of my approval will reduce the impact of aircraft noise on communities as raised in Petition EN6689. The full set of conditions as well as a statement detailing the reasons for my decision are available at:
infrastructure.gov.au/infrastructure-transport-vehicles/aviation/airports/ministerial-decisions.

The new runway will bring Melbourne Airport into line with Sydney and other globally-competitive airports. It will allow Melbourne Airport to cater for the demand of a growing city, providing better access for freight and passengers, and driving economic growth for years to come.

I note that under section 242(1) of the Airports Act 1996 an application can be made to the Administrative Review Tribunal (the ART) for review of my decision. The ART is currently considering two applications concerning my decision to approve the M3R MDP.
Thank you for taking the time to write to me on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, Ms C King
Jervis Bay Territory: Christians Minde
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence in relation to Petition EN6711, concerning heritage management of Christian's Minde Settlement in the Jervis Bay Territory.

Christian's Minde Settlement is a Commonwealth Heritage listed place protected under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act). Christian's Minde Settlement is managed by the Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development, Communications and the Arts (DITRDCA).

I note that this petition requests a range of actions aimed at improving the preservation of Christian's Minde Settlement's heritage values, including both built heritage and First Nations cultural heritage.

In relation to the endorsement and adoption of the 2015 Heritage Management Plan by Godden Mackay Logan, I am advised that this plan requires updates to reflect the current condition and maintenance requirements of Christian's Minde Settlement. I understand DITRDCA is taking steps to update the Heritage Management Plan and to address the lease and maintenance issues raised in the petition, ensuring the ongoing protection of the Commonwealth heritage values of the Christian's Minde Settlement.
Thank you again for your correspondence.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment and Water, Ms Plibersek
Medicare: Allied Health
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 10 February 2025 regarding a petition on the reinstatement of the Health Insurance Rebate (Rebate) eligibility for Bowen therapy.
I note the issues raised in petition number EN6717 and trust that the following information will be of assistance.

Bowen therapy is classified as an excluded natural therapy in the Private Health Insurance (Health Insurance Business) Rules 2018 made under the Private Health Insurance Act 2007. The Minister for Health and Aged Care and authorised delegates from the Department of Health and Aged Care can make and amend these Rules.

In 2019, the Rules were changed, and 16 natural therapies were excluded from the definition of private health insurance general treatment and became ineligible for the Rebate. This included Bowen therapy.

The exclusion of the 16 natural therapies was based on the outcomes of the 2015 Review of the Australian Government Rebate on Natural Therapies for Private Health Insurance. This review was supported by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC), which examined scientific literature about the effectiveness of the 16 natural therapies.

However, it was noted that many members of the community found these therapies beneficial, and that there may be more recent evidence of their clinical effectiveness. In response, in 2019 a further Natural Therapies Review (Review) of the excluded natural therapies was announced by the former Government.

The Review, led by Professor Michael Kidd AO, is examining additional evidence which has emerged since the previous review and will provide advice on whether any of the natural therapies should be covered by private health insurance. This coverage would make the therapies eligible for subsidy through the Rebate.

All evidence evaluations undertaken for the Review have been finalised with input from the Natural Therapies Review Expert Advisory Panel and the NHMRC's Natural Therapies Working Committee. Evidence evaluations for all the natural therapies in the Review will be considered by Professor Kidd, as Chair of the Review, in drafting his final report. It is expected he will finalise and provide his report and advice to Government shortly.
Thank you for bringing the concerns of the people signing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Vexatious Litigation
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 10 February 2025, referring to petition EN6729 regarding the protection of domestic violence victims from strategic litigation against public participation (SLAPP).

The Australian Government takes concerns about the misuse of the legal system by perpetrators of family and domestic violence very seriously. Following the National Cabinet meeting on 6 September 2024, the Government announced an audit of key Government systems to identify areas where they are being weaponised by perpetrators of family and domestic violence in order to stamp out opportunities for systems abuse. The audit is currently underway across government to identify key system vulnerabilities, their impact on victim-survivors and options for reform. The audit is leveraging existing reviews underway across the Government that seek to strengthen systems. It also will build on existing research and evidence that has indicated where systems are being misused.

The Government is also taking steps to improve the competency of professionals working in the family law system to identify, understand and respond appropriately to family and domestic violence, including systems abuse. The Government has co-funded measures with states and territories to improve the competency of judicial officers through the development and maintenance of a National Domestic and Family Violence Bench Book and delivery of the Family Violence in the Court training program. These initiatives form part of a $12.6 million package provided by the Government in the 2022-23 Budget for accredited sexual and family violence response training for frontline workers, legal practitioners, the judiciary, and the criminal justice sector.

In relation to protecting victims that report matters to police, I note that in September 2023 Commonwealth, state and territory Attorneys-General approved amendments to model defamation law to extend the defence of absolute privilege to matters disclosed to police. This amendment to model laws aims to alleviate concerns that such reporting could lead to defamation claims. Defamation law is primarily the responsibility of state and territory governments which are at varying stages of implementing the model law amendments.

While the Government is not currently considering express anti-SLAPP legislation, there are existing mechanisms in place to assist with preventing the misuse of court processes. For example, the federal and family courts can make orders to prevent misuse of court processes, including by making vexatious proceedings orders. Vexatious proceedings include proceedings that are an abuse of process, instituted without reasonable grounds, or instituted or conducted for a wrongful purpose including to harass, annoy, cause delay or detriment.

The court may also prohibit a person from instituting proceedings or make other orders it considers appropriate. The court may make a vexatious proceedings order on its own initiative or after receiving an application from a person who has an interest in the matter.

Family courts can also make harmful proceedings orders which would prevent someone instituting proceedings under the Family Law Act 1975 without first seeking the court's agreement. Harmful proceedings are proceedings that may result in harm to another party, or to a child. The kinds of harms could include major mental distress, psychological harm or oppression, behaviour which causes a detrimental effect on the other party's capacity to care for a child, or financial harm. The court may make a harmful proceedings order on its own initiative or after receiving an application from one of the parties to a matter.

I note also that the Civil Dispute Resolution Act 2011 requires parties to civil proceedings in a federal court, unless an exception applies, to file a statement of the sincere and genuine attempts that have been made to resolve the dispute before proceeding with litigation. Under this Act, the court may take such statements into account when exercising its powers and performing its functions, including when exercising its discretion to award costs.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus KC
Judiciary
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 10 February 2025, referring to me petition EN6746 which relates to the establishment of a federal judicial commission to investigate complaints made about federal judicial officers.

The Australian Government is committed to integrity, fairness and accountability across all public institutions. One of the key pillars of the Government's broader integrity agenda is reinforcing public trust in the judicial system.

I note that the Government agreed in-principle to the recommendation of the Australian Law Reform Commission that the Government should establish a federal judicial commission (Without Fear or Favour: Judicial Impartiality and the Law on Bias, ALRC Report 138, recommendation 5).

A taskforce was created within the Attorney-General's Department to undertake scoping work and consult on the merits and design of a commission. The design and timing of the establishment of a federal judicial commission continues to be under consideration by the Government.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus KC
Obesity
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 10 February 2025 regarding Petition EN6747 seeking to list Wegovy (R) (semaglutide) on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) for obesity.

The Australian Government is committed to ensuring Australians have access to affordable medicines by listing medicines on the PBS that have been recommended by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC). The PBAC is an independent and expert body, comprising doctors, health professionals, health economists and consumer representatives. Under legislation, a medicine cannot be listed on the PBS unless the PBAC makes a recommendation in favour of listing.

When considering a medicine proposed for PBS listing, the PBAC is legally required to consider the comparative effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of the medicine compared to other available therapies. The PBAC's consideration is generally initiated when the pharmaceutical company responsible for a medicine applies for PBS listing for specific conditions. Pharmaceutical companies usually hold scientific data and other information necessary to inform the PBAC's consideration.

The PBAC has previously considered applications to list Wegovy on the PBS. At its March 2022 meeting, the PBAC did not recommend listing Wegovy on the PBS for obesity. The PBAC recognised the high burden of disease in Australia and welcomed input from a stakeholder forum held prior to the PBAC meeting. However, the application had poorly justified the eligible population, the modelled benefits were highly uncertain, and the listing was not considered cost-effective at the requested price. The PBAC considered that PBS listing of Wegovy would require an extremely high investment with very uncertain implications for the PBS and broader health budget.

At its November 2023 meeting, the PBAC considered a resubmission to list Wegovy on the PBS for the treatment of severe obesity despite prior participation in an appropriate lifestyle-based weight management intervention. The PBAC again did not recommend listing Wegovy on the PBS. The PBAC considered the resubmission did not provide a strong clinical rationale for the proposed PBS population and did not identify patients most likely to experience relatively large reductions in weight or long-term benefits from weight loss.

The PBAC acknowledged the high and urgent unmet clinical need for effective weight loss strategies for severe obesity, but considered that Wegovy was not cost-effective at the price proposed. The PBAC considered several issues remained outstanding, including that the resubmission had not provided new trial data on the cardiovascular benefits of Wegovy. The PBAC considered that the value of this therapy is for patients at high cardiometabolic risk who are most likely to achieve long-term benefits from weight loss. The PBAC offered the sponsor a solution-focused workshop with one or more members of the PBAC, prior to it making a resubmission.

Further information about the PBAC's consideration and outcome is available in the Public Summary Documents (PSDs) for these items. The PSDs set out the specific detail of the PBAC's consideration, and are published on the PBS website at:
www.pbs.gov.au/pbs/industry/ listing/elements/pbac-meetings/psd, searching by product or meeting date.

A PBAC outcome does not necessarily represent the PBAC's final views on the merits of a medicine. The PBAC meets regularly and would consider further applications from Novo Nordisk Pharmaceuticals Pty Ltd concerning PBS listing of Wegovy for obesity. Pharmaceutical companies are private entities, and each company makes its own decisions about availability of its medicines, pricing of its medicines in the private market (outside the PBS), and whether it will apply for PBS listing. The Government cannot compel companies to submit applications.

On 6 March 2025, I wrote to the Chair of the PBAC to request that the PBAC provide advice to the Government on equitable access to medicines for the treatment of obesity in Australia. This may include, but not be limited to, the Australian population cohorts most likely to benefit from the potential future availability of Wegovy, or other anti-obesity medications such as tirzepatide, through the PBS. I also requested advice from the PBAC on the optimal duration of subsidisation, noting the limited long term safety data on the use of these medicines, and on whether these medicines are effective standalone therapies or best used in combination with other interventions, such as bariatric surgery or supporting models of care to achieve optimal patient outcomes.

The PBAC has previously recognised that equitable access to pharmacoptherapy is only one aspect of the necessary public health response to obesity in Australia. The availability of consistent, standardised models of care and wraparound allied health services is essential. The advice that I have requested will assist sponsors in making future submissions to the PBAC for anti-obesity medicines and in PBAC's consideration of those submissions.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Family Law
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email dated 10 February 2025 to the Minister for Social Services, the Hon Amanda Rishworth MP, concerning petition number EN6752, which raises matters relating to child support. The Minister has asked me to respond to you on her behalf.

The Australian Government shares the concerns raised in the petition about the lives that are lost each year to suicide in Australia. The National Suicide Prevention Office ensures the coordination of whole-of-government capability to deliver a national approach to reducing suicide rates in Australia.

Lifeline provides confidential online, phone and face-to-face crisis support and suicide prevention services for persons experiencing a personal crisis, 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. The service is available throughout Australia and can be contacted on 13 11 14 or online at lifeline.org.au.

I acknowledge the request in the petition to exclude overtime from the calculation of child support assessments. Generally, child support assessments are based on a parent's adjusted taxable income for the last relevant year of income. Where a parent's income has decreased by 15 per cent from their adjusted taxable income for the last relevant year, they have the option to lodge an estimate of income for the current financial year to reflect their current financial circumstances.

Child support legislation also allows for the exclusion of additional income for a period of 3 years from separation to assist either parent with re-establishment costs. Parents may earn this additional income from a variety of sources, such as overtime or taking on a second job. This provision is subject to a 3-year time limit because parents will generally achieve greater stability in their arrangements the longer they have been separated.

I also note that where a parent considers their assessment is unfair due to the special circumstances of their particular case, they have the option to seek a change of assessment. The change of assessment process allows Services Australia to examine the broader financial circumstances of both parents and vary the rate of child support where appropriate.

These policies reflect the Government's position that the Child Support Scheme (the Scheme) should be based on the principle that parents support their children in line with their financial capacities.

The Government is committed to improving the Scheme over the longer term and is progressing key recommendations made by the Joint Select Committee into Australia's Family Law System. The Government has established the Child Support Expert Panel and commissioned costs of children and related research as part of a review of the child support formula to ensure the Scheme continues to meet the needs of Australian families.
The Minister appreciates you bringing this matter to her attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Social Security, Ms Thwaites
Endometriosis
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 10 February 2025 regarding petition number EN6754, which requests the House to consider Newcastle as a site for an Endometriosis and Pelvic Pain Clinic (EPPC).

On 9 February 2025, the Australian Government announced a $573.3 million strengthening Medicare women's health package to provide additional support to women via a suite of measures. Part of this package was the announcement of an expansion of the EPPCs, that includes the provision of funding to establish 11 new EPPCs. This funding will be directed to ensure there will be at least one EPPC in each Primary Health Network (PHN) across Australia, making it easier for women and girls to get the care and support they need closer to home.

As the Hunter New England and Central Coast (Hunter) PHN does not currently have an EPPC, it will be eligible to apply for a new EPPC under this expansion. For new EPPCs to be determined, the Hunter PHN will be invited to nominate existing GP practice(s) in the region to apply for a grant opportunity. The nominated GP practices should already be specialising in women's health services, with the purpose of this funding aimed at improving provision of diagnosis, treatment and management of endometriosis, menopause and pelvic pain in a primary care setting.
You can find more information about the existing clinics, including their locations, at:
www.heaIth.gov.au/our-work/ endometriosis-and-pelvic-pain-clinics.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Health and Aged Care, Ms Kearney

subdebateinfo.title: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder and Autism

p.span: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder and Autism
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 10 February 2025 regarding Petition Number EN6801 to reduce the cost of assessment for autism and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).
The Australian Government recognises that people with, or experiencing symptoms of, ADHD and autism should be able to access high quality evidence-based assessment, treatment and support.

You may be aware that the National Roadmap to Improve the Health and Mental Health of Autistic People (Autism Health Roadmap) was released on 25 February 2025 which can be found on the Department of Health and Aged Care website at www.health.gov.au. The Autism Health Roadmap was developed over the past two years in close collaboration with many autistic people and autism community members. The Autism Health Roadmap sets out concrete steps that recognise what will make the Australian health and mental health system provide better care for autistic people, with six focus areas with specific outcomes and actions.

The Autism Health Roadmap forms part of the National Autism Strategy, which is intended to improve outcomes for all autistic people in Australia by coordinating a national approach to services and supports. This includes access to services, health care, education and employment. This Roadmap represents the Government's commitment to improve the health and mental health outcomes of autistic people.

The Government's response to the report into the assessment and support services for people with ADHD was tabled on 12 December 2024 and outlines what the Government is doing and future plans to address the 15 recommendations the committee has made. You can access the ADHD Senate Inquiry and Government Response through the Parliament of Australia website at:
www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Senate/Community_Affairs/ADHD.

The Government subsidises services through the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS) to help people with a professional diagnosis for autism and/or ADHD. MBS time-based attendance items for psychiatry include higher benefit items for longer consultations to manage more complex issues. These services can also be provided by telehealth and replicate the same fees and Medicare benefits as the face-to-face items.

The Government understands that paying large out-of-pocket fees for treatment can cause significant financial hardship and stress. Whilst the Government is responsible for setting Medicare benefits to assist with access to privately rendered medical services listed on the MBS, it has no direct power to determine the fees charged by doctors or their billing practices. Doctors are encouraged to consider the personal circumstances of their patients when determining the fees they charge, and many do so.

The Medicare safety net assists patients with out-of-pocket costs by providing additional benefits once an annual out-of-pocket limit is reached. The Extended Medicare Safety Net (EMSN) provides an increase in benefits of up to 80% of out-of-pocket costs (once the annual threshold has been reached). All out-of-hospital out-of-pocket costs contribute to the EMSN. Further information about the EMSN is available from the Services Australia website at www.servicesaustralia.gov.au by searching the term 'Medicare Safety Nets' or on the MBS Online website at www.mbsonline.gov.au by searching the term 'Medicare Safety Net Arrangements-1 January 2023'.

The Government recognises that the MBS is only part of the solution and is investing in complementary models of mental health care to ensure Australians get the right level of care for their level of need, including those with autism and/or ADHD. In the 2024-25 Budget, the Government invested $361 million to expand the range and reach of free mental health services to better care cater for all Australians. This included funding for a new national early intervention service to ensure people can access support before their distress escalates and for an enhanced network of 61 Medicare Mental Health Centres which will offer free, walk-in, access to psychologist and psychiatrists.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
National Security
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence regarding Petition EN6817, foreign missions operating within places of worship in Australia.

Following receipt of your petition, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Department of Home Affairs have not been able to determine any instances or reporting of foreign consulates using religious places for official work.

Foreign diplomats have the right to attend religious places, as can all persons in Australia. The Australian Government expects all foreign officials and their dependants to respect Australian laws and community expectations.
Concerned members of the Australian community may report specific foreign interference activities to the National Security hotline on 1800 123 400 or email hotline@nationalsecurity.gov.au.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Miscarriage, Stillbirth and Neonatal Death
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 10 February 2025 providing petition EN6822 regarding pregnancy and infant loss.

The Australian Government funds a range of activities to support families impacted by these devastating occurrences. This includes investment in health and medical research in pregnancy loss and neonatal death, providing direct support through the complementary Medical Research Future Fund (MRFF) and the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC).

Through the MRFF, over $80 million had been awarded in December 2024 on research to support premature birth and pregnancy loss, and over $70 million from 2014 to 2023 on these areas through the NHMRC. A further $25 million has been made available for the MRFF Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research Initiative 2024: Infertility; Pregnancy·Loss and Menopause Grant Opportunity. This grant opportunity has the intended outcome of enhancing risk prediction to support effective interventions to improve pregnancy outcomes and generate evidence to inform prevention of pregnancy loss and neonatal death.

The Government also funds a range of national data collections to better understand pregnancy and childbirth in Australia. $1 million over two years was announced in the 2024-25 Budget for the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare (AIHW) to undertake a miscarriage data scoping study to identify and provide recommendations on options for national collection of miscarriage data and address key data gaps.

The AIHW maintains a national population-based cross-sectional collection of data on pregnancy and childbirth called the Australia National Perinatal Data Collection. It also holds the National Perinatal Mortality Data Collection, which collates data from state and territory sources to be used in the preparation of national perinatal death reports. The data set contains information on the deaths of babies in hospitals and in the community within the scope of the collection, which includes all live births and stillbirths of at least 20 weeks gestation or at least 400 grams birthweight, during pregnancy or birth or within 28 days of birth.

The Government also provides funding to the AIHW for the National Maternity Data Development Project (NMDDP), which is building the evidence base on maternal and perinatal morbidity and mortality to support the reporting of outcomes such as those outlined in Woman-centred Care: Strategic directions for Australian maternity services and the National Stillbirth Action and Implementation Plan 2020-2030 (Stillbirth Action Plan). Additionally, the NMDDP supports the establishment of a national data linkage project to enable meaningful collection on longer term outcomes for women and their babies.

The Government funds a range of activities to prevent pregnancy and infant loss, and to support families who have experienced these tragic events. The Stillbirth Action Plan aims to reduce preventable stillbirths after 28 weeks with a primary goal of reducing stillbirth rates by 20% over five years. It also aims to ensure families experiencing stillbirth receive respectful and supportive bereavement care. The Stillbirth Action Plan recognises that some groups, including First Nations communities and some migrant and refugee communities, experience higher rates of stillbirth and includes actions to address these inequities.
Since the release of the Stillbirth Action Plan, a range of activities have been funded including:
developing a new Clinical Care Standard for Stillbirth
updating stillbirth related guidelines for health professionals
delivering stillbirth education and awareness programs
national implementation of the Safer Baby Bundle, an initiative providing evidence-based information to maternity health care providers to reduce the risk of stillbirth
adaptation of the Safer Baby Bundle for First Nations women and migrant and refugee women who are at increased risk of stillbirth
activities to increase stillbirth autopsy rates
miscarriage and stillbirth bereavement support programs
programs to support families experiencing stillbirth, including the Red Nose Hospital to Home Program.

In 2024-25, through the combined Federal Budget and Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook processes, the Government has allocated a total of $22.9 million to support women and families impacted by stillbirth and miscarriage, reduce stigma and shame, and remove barriers to providing best-practice care. This builds upon the $23 million investment announced in 2022-23 to deliver high quality, evidence-based care for women and families from higher-risk population groups who have experienced stillbirth or miscarriage, including First Nations people, multicultural families, refugee and migrant communities, women and families living in rural and remote areas, and women younger than 20 years.

The Government is also aware that each year close to 25,000 babies are born prematurely (before 37 full weeks of gestation) in Australia. In recognition of preterm birth as the single greatest cause of death in young children and one of the major causes of lifelong disability, the Government funded the National Preterm Birth Prevention Program, which was a world first initiative aimed at safely reducing the rate of preterm birth.

Early data from the Program shows a reduction of 11% in early-term births, which equates to more than 4,000 early births avoided. Further funding of $5.8 million over two years was announced in the 2024-25 Budget to continue strategies to prevent preterm and early-term birth across Australia.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Animal Welfare
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence dated 10 February 2025, concerning petition number EN6862 on protecting pet rabbits from calicivirus (or Rabbit Haemorrhagic Disease Virus—RHDV). I acknowledge the concerns the petition raises and understand that pet rabbits are much loved and may be an important part of families.

Unlike domestic pet rabbits, wild rabbits are a costly pest, causing over $200 million in lost agricultural production annually and are a significant threat to biodiversity, affecting 304 nationally threatened plant and animal species. Wild rabbits decrease agricultural productivity and can cause wide scale land degradation and erosion. They also compete with native animals for food. If wild rabbit populations are left unmanaged, they will cause even greater environmental damage, particularly following severe bushfires and floods when native vegetation and wildlife are likely to be under additional stress.

The management of established pest animals such as wild rabbits is primarily the responsibility of the relevant state or territory government, along with landholders. Therefore, management activities, including use of RHDVl-K5 as a biological control agent, are governed by relevant state and territory legislation and can only be carried out under conditions set down in a specific permit issued by the Australian Pesticides & Veterinary Medicines Authority (APVMA) under Commonwealth legislation (Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Code Act 1994).

I encourage individuals who have concerns about protecting their pet rabbits against RHDV to contact their relevant state or territory government to seek advice on the best channels to receive relevant communications on planned RHDV releases.

As an example, the New South Wales (NSW) Government makes public notices to veterinarians in the relevant local government areas advising of planned releases of RHDV and encouraging vets to inform client of the need to vaccinate their pet rabbits. To protect pet and production rabbits from possible RHDV infection, owners should implement good hygiene practices, ensure animals are protected through appropriate housing and insect proofing, ensure rabbits are vaccinated, and avoid contact with other rabbits—whether wild (feral) rabbits or pet rabbits from outside the household. Additionally, rabbit owners should contact their local veterinarian for advice on biosecurity measures specific to their pet or facility.

I note the request for assistance from the Australian Government for funding to reduce the cost of RHDV vaccines. While the Australian Government does not provide direct support for the purchase of vaccines for domestic rabbits, government agencies consider import and registration applications for vaccines, assessing possible risk to human and animal health and the environment. The Australian government provides national leadership, coordination and invests strategically in established pest animal and weed management where it is in the national interest. It is in the national interest to continue to support the use of biocontrol agents for wild rabbits, to promote agricultural productivity and to protect our natural environment.

There are now two vaccines available for use in rabbits in Australia. The Cylap(R) vaccine currently used in Australia is effective against RHDV1 but may only provide partial protection against the RHDV2 strain. The Filavac VHD K C + V vaccine is an inactivated bivalent vaccine for rabbits which can provide protection against both RHDV1 and RHDV2, and this vaccine was approved in May 2022 for emergency use in Australia.

There has been some confusion between the RHDV1 (K5) variant and the discovery in 2015 of RHDV2 in wild and pet rabbits. RHDV2 is a different virus to RHDV1 and K5. RHDV2 has not been released as a biological control agent by any Australian government. It is not known how the outbreak of RHDV2 virus occurred in Australia, but it is currently the dominant strain causing deaths in domestic rabbits.
Once again, thank you for taking the time to write to me. I trust the information provided is of assistance to the petitions committee.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Ms Collins
Health Care: Maternity Services
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 10 February 2025 regarding petition EN6873 addressing the disproportionate impacts women have in rural Australia due to funding and service delivery limitations in maternity services.

The Australian Government recognises the importance of maternity care—Australian families need to have access to safe, high-quality, respectful maternity care. The planning and delivery of Australian maternity services is predominantly undertaken by states and territories, with the Government providing national direction and supporting efforts to improve care and outcomes.

Under the National Health Reform Agreement (NHRA) and the Medicare Benefits. Schedule (MBS), the Government provides a significant funding contribution to assist states and territories with the costs of public hospital and community health services, including maternity services and where birthing services are available.

All Australian governments are collaborating closely to develop national maternity workforce solutions. Queensland and the New South Wales Governments are leading the development of the National Maternity Workforce Strategy with ongoing jurisdictional and Commonwealth collaboration.
Woman-centred Care Strategy

The Australian Government has developed the Woman-centred care: Strategic directions for Australian maternity services (Woman-centred Care Strategy) to provide national strategic directions to support Australia's high-quality maternity care system and enable improvements in line with contemporary practice, evidence, and international developments.

The Woman-centred Care Strategy recognises that women want to access maternity care in their geographic location and that outreach services and telehealth care enhance maternity care in rural and regional areas.
Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS)

The Government is committed to addressing issues that impact women's access to midwifery continuity of care. From 1 March 2025, pregnant women and new mothers will be able to access flexible, high-quality and tailored maternity care that supports improved maternity care outcomes by introducing: a new MBS antenatal and postnatal attendance item of at least 90 minutes, the inclusion of a birth debrief and mental health screening as part of the final postnatal attendance, and a new complex antenatal attendance item leading to hospital admission.

These measures were approved in response to MBS Review Taskforce (Taskforce) recommendations and align with the Senate Inquiry into reproductive healthcare's report 'Ending the postcode lottery—Addressing barriers to reproductive healthcare in Australia'. The changes are complemented and strengthened by the recent removal of the legislated requirement for specified collaborative arrangements between participating midwives and medical practitioners, to render MBS services and prescribe Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme medications.
Medicare for Home Birth

The MBS does not provide a rebate for intrapartum home birth items for participating midwives. State and territory governments support a range of birthing arrangements, including home birth programs delivered through public hospitals. Eligibility varies in each jurisdiction according to their guidelines. The Commonwealth provides funding support for these services under the National Health Reform Agreement.
There are currently 20 hospitals in Australia with publicly funded home birth programs. Five of those are a Modified Monash Model (MMM) category above 1.
Home Birth Service, Darwin, NT (MMM 2)
Midwifery Group Practice, Alice Springs, NT (MMM 6)
Byron Community Birthing Service, Byron Bay, NSW (MMM 4)
Sunbury Midwifery Group Practice, WA (MMM 2)
Broome Midwifery Group Practice, WA (in development) (MMM 6)

For a new service to be funded through the MBS, an assessment by the Medical Services Advisory Committee or MBS Continuous Review Advisory Committee is usually required. More information on both committee's and how to submit an application or review request is available on the Department of Health and Aged Care's website.
Midwife Professional Indemnity Scheme (MPIS)

In December 2024, the Government passed amendments to the Midwife Professional Indemnity (Commonwealth Contribution) Scheme Act 2010. These amendments expand the existing MPIS to cover claims arising from out-of-hospital births, including homebirths and Birthing on Country services. They will come into effect from 1 July 2025.

Changes to the MPIS do not directly alter funding or access to homebirth for patients. By expanding the available insurance coverage, the Government is enabling midwives to offer a wider range of services. In turn, this will support women in choosing the birthing option that best suits their needs and preferences, including culturally safe care for First Nations mothers.
National Health Reform Agreement (NHRA)

On 5 February 2025, a 12-month extension to the current NHRA 2020-2025 Addendum was agreed between all governments. The 12-month extension locks in over $33 billion in health funding to states in 2025-26, including more than $2 billion in additional growth funding; and $1.7 billion through a one-time fixed funding boost for hospital and related health services. The 12-month extension provides financial certainty for public hospitals while allowing more time for the Commonwealth and states and territories to work together on longer term and more complex health and disability reforms. Officials will continue working on the 2025-2030 Addendum in good faith, to deliver vital structural reforms that reduce demand on public hospitals.

As agreed at National Cabinet, all governments will continue to progress negotiations on the next Addendum to the NHRA, which will make our system more sustainable and ensure that now, and into the future, every Australian can access the health care they need when and where "they need it. Negotiations have included consideration of recommendations from the NHRA Mid Term Review. The Mid Term Review was a report to all governments, it included a recommendation (recommendation 13) to the develop and implement bundled payments within the NHRA, with an initial focus on maternity care.
Maternity Support Services in the Vass Valley, New South Wales

At the 2024-25 Budget, the Government announced that it would 'provide funding to support the New South Wales Government to establish a maternity care service, which will provide women residing in the Vass Valley with greater access to maternity support services closer to home.' This is a Commonwealth commitment of $4.7 million to fund a new Women's and Family Maternity Care Centre at Vass that will provide a midwifery-led model of care. This midwifery-led model would provide quality maternity services for women and families residing in the rural surrounds of the Vass Valley.
Diagnostic Imaging Services Review

The Government's 2024-25 Budget included a review of select diagnostic imaging services, including obstetric and gynaecological ultrasound items. The aim of this review is to determine whether current items reflect best practices and evidence-based guidelines, align with the time, complexity, and costs of providing the services, and support patient access while ensuring the quality and safety of ultrasound imaging services. The review will also assess imaging requestor rights, with the aim of ensuring that health care providers, including Endorsed Midwives, have access to appropriate imaging.
Maternity Patient Reported Outcome and Experience Measures

A priority area for action of the Woman-centred Care Strategy, as agreed by Health Ministers in April 2023, is to strengthen and expand national data on patient reported measures of outcomes and experiences. While some health services at the local level have mechanisms in place to obtain feedback from patients of their services, including in relation to maternity care, there is little standardisation or collation of this information. Additionally, there is no national reporting of maternity patient reported outcome and experience measures (PROMs and PREMs) in Australia.

The Australian Government provides funding to the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare (AIHW) for the National Maternity Data Development Project, which supports continued development of nationally consistent maternal and perinatal data collections in, Australia since 2011.

It continues to build the evidence base on maternal and perinatal morbidity and mortality to support the reporting and review of maternity outcomes such as those outlined in the Woman-centred Care Strategy and the National Stillbirth Action and Implementation Plan.
Under this project, the AIHW provided a research brief to the department in January 2025 on Patient reported outcome and experience measures for women giving birth in Australia.

The brief explores what PROMs and PREMs are, which PROMs and PREMs are used for maternity care, if data could be collected alongside the National Perinatal Data Collection and provides recommendations for next steps in progressing work in this area. The department will consider the recommendations in consultation with jurisdictions via the National Maternity Strategic Advisory Group.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
E-Cigarettes and Vaping Products
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of Monday 10 February 2025 regarding petition number EN6879, requesting that the House of Representatives take action to charge Big Tobacco in relation to people aged under 18 becoming addicted to vaping products.

The Australian Government shares your concerns about youth vaping. The Government has progressed a comprehensive range of measures and reforms in partnership with states and territories to reduce smoking and vaping through stronger legislation, enforcement, education and support.

The Therapeutic Goods and Other Legislation Amendment (Vaping Reforms) Act 2024 commenced on 1 July 2024 enacting key changes, including limiting access of therapeutic vapes to pharmacies and prohibiting the importation, domestic manufacture, supply, commercial possession and advertisement of disposable single use and nontherapeutic vapes.

The reforms do not prohibit the sale of all vaping products. From 1 October 2024, patients over the age of 18 can buy therapeutic vapes with a nicotine concentration of 20mg/ml or less from a participating pharmacy without a prescription, to support smoking cessation and the management of nicotine dependence, subject to certain conditions and where state and territory law allows. The patient must talk with the pharmacist before purchasing. People under 18 years need a prescription to access vapes, where state and territory laws allow, to ensure they get appropriate medical advice and supervision.

The Government's vaping reforms are focussed on protecting young people and other Australians from the harms of vaping while ensuring those with a legitimate need to access therapeutic vapes can continue to do so.

The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA), part of the Department of Health and Aged Care, and other Commonwealth and state/territory government agencies are working together to enforce the vaping reforms. The TGA takes action against those unlawfully advertising, importing and supplying vaping goods (whether or not these responsible parties are related to the tobacco industry) using a variety of investigative and enforcement powers, including taking court action.

The Government also continues to provide support for people who vape and/or smoke to quit and remain tobacco and vape free. Support is available from health professionals such as GPs, nurses and pharmacists. Confidential advice is also available through Quitline (13 78 48). Smoking cessation products that have been approved by the TGA following a rigorous assessment of their safety, quality, and efficacy also continue to be available, and some products are subsidised under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.

New initiatives from the Government have provided or enabled targeted support through increased education and information, and improved access to services. These initiatives build on existing measures and resources, and include:
the creation of an online cessation hub that contains information, tools, resources and a system to direct consumers to the best support mechanisms to assist them to quit smoking and vaping
improved access to Quitline and cessation support services across the country
the redevelopment of the My Quit Buddy app to provide both smoking and vaping cessation support
new clinical guidance for health professionals on smoking and vaping cessation
support for health professionals through continued funding of the National Quit Centre
national public health campaigns to reduce smoking and vaping rates, including campaigns focused on youth vaping cessation.
